==Events== * March 28 - At the [[49th Academy Awards]], [[Rocky]] picks up the [[Academy Award for Best Picture]]. [[Peter Finch]], [[Faye Dunaway]], and [[Beatrice Straight]] all win Oscars for their performances in ''[[Network (1976 film)|Network]]'' for [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]], [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]], and [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]], while [[Jason Robards]] wins for [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actor]] for his performance in ''[[All the President's Men (film)|All the President's Men]].'' He will win again the following year, becoming the only person to win two consecutive Best Supporting Actor awards. * May 25 - ''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars]]'' opens in theaters and becomes the [[List of highest-grossing films|highest-grossing film]] of the year. The film revolutionizes the use of [[special effects]] in film and television production. It also embraces the notion of omitting any sort of opening credits sequence. Lucas, told by the [[Screen Actors Guild]] that he must have an opening credits sequence, instead distributes the film independently, sans the opening credits. The film's release is often considered one of the most important events in the film history. *June 22 - [[Walt Disney Productions]] releases ''[[The Rescuers]]'', which brings back an interest in animation that had been lost to both film-goers and critics throughout the beginning of the 1970s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cataroo.com/DBrescu.html|title=Don Bluth The Disney Years: The Rescuers|work=cataroo.com|accessdate=3 April 2017}}</ref> *November 16 - ''[[Close Encounters of the Third Kind]]'' opens to widespread critical acclaim and massive box office success, becoming one of the top-grossing films to date and cementing Steven Spielberg's status as one of the most talented and profitable film directors of all time. * The average price of a movie ticket in the United States is about $2.25.

A. Macedonski''', '''Macedonschi''' or '''Macedonsky'''; March 14, 1854 – November 24, 1920) was a [[Romania]]n poet, novelist, dramatist and literary critic, known especially for having promoted French [[Symbolism (arts)|Symbolism]] in his native country, and for leading the [[Symbolist movement in Romania|Romanian Symbolist movement]] during its early decades. A forerunner of local [[modernist literature]], he is the first local author to have used [[free verse]], and claimed by some to have been the first in modern [[European literature]]. Within the framework of [[Literature of Romania|Romanian literature]], Macedonski is seen by critics as second only to [[List of national poets|national poet]] [[Mihai Eminescu]]; as leader of a [[Cosmopolitanism|cosmopolitan]] and [[Aestheticism|aestheticist]] trend formed around his ''[[Literatorul]]'' journal, he was diametrically opposed to the inward-looking traditionalism of Eminescu and his school.
Debuting as a [[Neo-romanticism|Neoromantic]] in the [[Wallachia]]n tradition, Macedonski went through the [[Literary realism|Realist]]-[[Naturalism (literature)|Naturalist]] stage deemed "social poetry", while progressively adapting his style to Symbolism and [[Parnassianism]], and repeatedly but unsuccessfully attempting to impose himself in the [[Francophone]] world. Despite having theorized "instrumentalism", which reacted against the traditional guidelines of poetry, he maintained a lifelong connection with [[Neoclassicism]] and its ideal of purity. Macedonski's quest for excellence found its foremost expression in his recurring motif of life as a [[Hajj|pilgrimage to Mecca]], notably used in his critically acclaimed ''[[Nights (Macedonski)|Nights]]'' cycle. The stylistic stages of his career are reflected in the collections ''[[Prima verba]]'', ''[[Poezii (Macedonski)|Poezii]]'', and ''[[Excelsior (Macedonski)|Excelsior]]'', as well as in the [[Fantasy literature|fantasy novel]] ''[[Thalassa, Le Calvaire de feu]]''. In old age, he became the author of [[Rondel (poem)|rondels]], noted for their detached and serene vision of life, in contrast with his earlier combativeness.
In parallel to his literary career, Macedonski was a civil servant, notably serving as [[Prefect (Romania)|prefect]] in the [[Budjak]] and [[Northern Dobruja]] during the late 1870s. As journalist and militant, his allegiance fluctuated between the [[Liberalism and radicalism in Romania|liberal current]] and [[conservatism]], becoming involved in polemics and controversies of the day. Of the long series of publications he founded, ''Literatorul'' was the most influential, notably hosting his early conflicts with the ''[[Junimea]]'' literary society. These targeted [[Vasile Alecsandri]] and especially Eminescu, their context and tone becoming the cause of a major rift between Macedonski and his public. This situation repeated itself in later years, when Macedonski and his ''[[Forța Morală]]'' magazine began campaigning against the ''Junimist'' dramatist [[Ion Luca Caragiale]], whom they falsely accused of [[plagiarism]]. During [[World War I]], the poet aggravated his critics by supporting the [[Central Powers]] against Romania's alliance with the [[Allies of World War I|Entente side]]. His biography was also marked by an enduring interest in [[esotericism]], numerous attempts to become recognized as an inventor, and an enthusiasm for [[cycling]].
The scion of a political and aristocratic family, the poet was the son of [[Alexandru D. Macedonski|General Alexandru Macedonski]], who served as [[Ministry of Defense (Romania)|Defense Minister]], and the grandson of [[Wallachian uprising of 1821|1821 rebel]] [[Dimitrie Macedonski]]. Both his son [[Alexis Macedonski|Alexis]] and grandson [[Soare Macedonski|Soare]] were known painters.
==Biography==
===Early life and family=== [[File:Macedonski Rondelul trecutului.png|thumb|260px|Manuscript version for one of Macedonski's late poems, referencing his family's estates on the [[Amaradia River (Dolj)|Amaradia Valley]]]]
The poet's paternal family had arrived in [[Wallachia]] during the early 19th century. Of [[South Slavs|South Slav]] ([[Serbs|Serb]] or [[Bulgarians|Bulgarian]])<ref>Călinescu, p.517; Vianu, Vol.II, p.330</ref> or [[Aromanians|Aromanian]]<ref name="Călinescu, p.517">Călinescu, p.517</ref><ref name="vztcron">{{ro icon}} Virgiliu Z. Teodorescu, [http://www.cronicaromana.ro/index.php?editie=347&art=16363 "Alexandru Macedonski - 150 de ani de la naștere"], in ''[[Cronica Română]]'', March 15, 2004</ref> origin, they claimed to have descended from Serb insurgents in [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]]-ruled [[Macedonia (region)|Macedonia]].<ref name="Călinescu, p.517" /> Alexandru's grandfather Dimitrie and Dimitrie's brother [[Pavel Macedonski|Pavel]] participated in the 1821 uprising against the [[Phanariotes|Phanariote]] administration, and in alliance with the [[Filiki Eteria]]; Dimitrie made the object of controversy when, during the final stage of the revolt, he sided with the Eteria in its confrontation with Wallachian leader [[Tudor Vladimirescu]], taking an active part in the latter's killing.<ref>Călinescu, p.517; Vianu, Vol.II, p.333-334</ref> Both Macedonski brothers had careers in the [[Wallachian military forces]], at a time when the country was governed by [[Russian Empire|Imperial Russian]] envoys, when the ''[[Regulamentul Organic]]'' regime recognized the family as belonging to Wallachia's nobility.<ref>Călinescu, p.517; Vianu, Vol.II, p.332</ref> Dimitrie married Zoe, the daughter an [[Russians|ethnic Russian]] or [[Poles|Polish]] officer; their son, the Russian-educated Alexandru, climbed in the military and political hierarchy, joining the [[Romanian Land Forces|unified Land Forces]] after his political ally, [[Alexander John Cuza]], was elected ''[[Domnitor]]'' and the two [[Danubian Principalities]] became [[United Principalities|united Romania]].<ref>Anghelescu, p.8; Călinescu, p.517, 518; Vianu, Vol.II, p.334-338</ref> Both the officer's uncle Pavel<ref name="Călinescu, p.517" /> and brother Mihail<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.334</ref> were amateur poets.
Macedonski's mother, Maria Fisența (also ''Vicenț'' or ''Vicența''), was from an aristocratic environment, being the scion of [[Oltenia]]n [[Boyars of Wallachia and Moldavia|boyar]]s.<ref>Călinescu, p.517-518, 519; Vianu, Vol.II, p.330, 338-339</ref> Through her father, she may have descended from Russian immigrants who had been absorbed into Oltenia's nobility.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.339. Călinescu also renders the family's alternative theory, according to which their ancestors were [[Italo-Russian]] (p.517).</ref> Maria had been adopted by the boyar Dumitrache Pârâianu, and the couple had inherited the Adâncata and Pometești estates in [[Goiești]], on the [[Amaradia River (Dolj)|Amaradia Valley]].<ref>Călinescu, p.517-518; Vianu, Vol.II, p.339-341</ref>
Both the poet and his father were dissatisfied with accounts of their lineage, contradicting them with an account that researchers have come to consider spurious.<ref>Anghelescu, p.7; Călinescu, p.517; Vianu, Vol.II, p.330-332</ref> Although adherents of the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]], the Macedonskis traced their origin to [[Rogala coat of arms|Rogala]]-bearing [[Lithuanian nobility]] from the defunct [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]].<ref>Anghelescu, p.7; Călinescu, p.517, 519, 520; Vianu, Vol.II, p.330, 331-332</ref> While the writer perpetuated his father's claim, it is possible that he also took pride in investigating his [[Balkans|Balkan]] roots: according to literary historian [[Tudor Vianu]], who, as a youth, was a member of his circle, this tendency is attested by two of Macedonski's poems from the 1880s, where the South Slavs appear as icons of freedom.<ref>The pieces are named ''Vânt de stepe'' ("[[Steppe]] Wind") and ''Stepa'' ("The Steppe"). Vianu (Vol.II, p.333) places emphasis on "[Macedonski's] soul [...] where so many of his ancestors' instincts resided."</ref> Vianu's contemporary, literary historian [[George Călinescu]], postulated that, although the family had been absorbed into the ethnic and cultural majority, the poet's origin served to enrich [[Culture of Romania|local culture]] by linking it to a "[[Thracians|Thracian]]" tradition and the spirit of "adventurers".<ref>Călinescu, p.517, 974, 976</ref>
The family moved often, following General Macedonski's postings. Born in [[Bucharest]], Macedonski-son was the third of four siblings, the oldest of whom was a daughter, Caterina.<ref>An amateur poet, she later married into the [[Ghica family]], but divorced, marrying a second time, to a [[France|Frenchman]] by the name of Leboeuf (Vianu, Vol.II, p.340).</ref> Before the age of six, he was a sickly and nervous child, who is reported to have had regular [[tantrum]]s.<ref>Călinescu, p.518; Suciu, p.104; Vianu, Vol.II, p.342</ref> In 1862, his father sent him to school in Oltenia, and he spent most time in the Amaradia region.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.340-341">Vianu, Vol.II, p.340-341</ref> The nostalgia he felt for the landscape later made him consider writing an ''Amărăzene'' ("Amaradians") cycle, of which only one poem was ever completed.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.340-341" /> He was attending the [[Carol I National College|Carol I High School]] in [[Craiova]] and, according to his official record, graduated in 1867.<ref>Călinescu, p.518; Vianu, Vol.II, p.342</ref>
Macedonski's father had by then become known as an authoritarian commander, and, during his time in [[Târgu Ocna]], faced a [[mutiny]] which only his wife could stop by pleading with the soldiers (an episode which made an impression on the future poet).<ref>Călinescu, p.518; Vianu, Vol.II, p.334</ref> A stern parent, he took an active part in educating his children.<ref>Călinescu, p.518; Vianu, Vol.II, p.334-335</ref> Having briefly served as [[Ministry of Defense (Romania)|Defense Minister]], the general was mysteriously dismissed by Cuza in 1863, and his pension became the topic of a political scandal. It ended only under the rule of [[Carol I of Romania|Carol I]], Cuza's [[Hohenzollern]] successor, when [[Parliament of Romania|Parliament]] voted against increasing the sum to the level demanded by its recipient.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.337">Vianu, Vol.II, p.337</ref> Having preserved a negative impression of the [[Romanian plebiscite, 1866|1866 plebiscite]], during which Cuza's dethronement had been confirmed,<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.423">Vianu, Vol.II, p.423</ref> Macedonski remained a committed opponent of the new ruler. As a youth and adult, he sought to revive his father's cause, and included allusions to the perceived injustice in at least one poem.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.337" /> After spending the last months of his life protesting against the authorities, Macedonski-father fell ill and died in September 1869, leaving his family to speculate that he had been murdered by political rivals.<ref>Anghelescu, p.8; Călinescu, p.518; Vianu, Vol.II, p.338, 344</ref>
===Debut years=== [[File:Alexandru Macedonski - prima pagina - Prima verba.png|thumb|First page of ''[[Prima verba]]'', 1872]]
Macedonski left Romania in 1870, traveling through [[Austria-Hungary]] and spending time in [[Vienna]], before visiting Switzerland and possibly other countries; according to one account, it was here that he may have first met (and disliked) his rival poet [[Mihai Eminescu]], at a time a Viennese student.<ref name="mzrivalul">{{ro icon}} [[Mihai Zamfir]], [http://www.romlit.ro/index.pl/rivalul_lui_eminescu "Rivalul lui Eminescu"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 27/2009</ref> Macedonski's visit was meant to be preparation for entering the [[University of Bucharest]], but he spent much of his time in the [[Bohemianism|bohemian environment]], seeking entertainment and engaging in romantic escapades.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.342-344</ref> He was however opposed to the lifestyle choices of people his age, claiming that they were engaged in "orgy after orgy".<ref name="aonarco22">{{ro icon}} [[Andrei Oișteanu]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20080509083836/http://www.revista22.ro/html/index.php?art=4538&nr=2008-05-07 "Scriitorii români și narcoticele (2). Macedonski și 'literatura stupefiantelor' "], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 948, May 2008</ref> At around that date, the young author had begun to perfect a style heavily influenced by [[Romanticism]], and in particular by his Wallachian predecessors [[Dimitrie Bolintineanu]] and [[Ion Heliade Rădulescu]].<ref name="mzrivalul"/><ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.342-343, 365, 388, 394, 479</ref> He was for a while in [[Styria]], at [[Bad Gleichenberg]], a stay which, George Călinescu believes, may have been the result of a medical recommendation to help him counter excessive nervousness.<ref>Călinescu, p.518</ref> The landscape there inspired him to write an [[ode]].<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.342, 343</ref> Also in 1870, he published his first lyrics in [[George Bariț]]'s [[Transylvania]]n-based journal ''[[Telegraful Român]]''.<ref>Anghelescu, p.9</ref>
The following year, he left for Italy, where he visited [[Pisa]], [[Florence]], [[Venice]], and possibly other cities.<ref>Anghelescu, p.9; Călinescu, p.518; Vianu, Vol.II, p.343-344</ref> His records of the journey indicate that he was faced with financial difficulties and plagued by disease.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.343-344</ref> Macedonski also claimed to have attended college lectures in these cities, and to have spent significant time studying at [[University of Pisa|Pisa University]], but this remains uncertain.<ref>Anghelescu, p.9; Călinescu, p.518; Vianu, Vol.II, p.343</ref> He eventually returned to Bucharest, where he entered the Faculty of Letters (which he never attended regularly).<ref>Anghelescu, p.9; Călinescu, p.518, 519</ref> According to Călinescu, Macedonski "did not feel the need" to attend classes, because "such a young man will expect society to render upon him its homages."<ref name="Călinescu, p.519">Călinescu, p.519</ref> He was again in Italy during spring 1872, soon after publishing his debut volume ''[[Prima verba]]'' ([[Latin]] for "First Word").<ref>Anghelescu, p.9; Vianu, Vol.II, p.343-344</ref> Having also written an anti-Carol piece, published in ''Telegraful Român'' during 1873, Macedonski reportedly feared political reprisals, and decided to make another visit to Styria and Italy while his case was being assessed.<ref>Anghelescu, p.9; Călinescu, p.518</ref> It was in Italy that he met French [[Musicology|musicologist]] [[Jules Combarieu]], with whom he corresponded sporadically over the following decades.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.341-342">Vianu, Vol.II, p.341-342</ref>
During that period, Macedonski became interested in the political scene and political journalism, first as a sympathizer of the [[Liberalism and radicalism in Romania|liberal-radical current]]—which, in 1875, organized itself around the [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]]. In 1874, back in Craiova, Macedonski founded a short-lived literary society known as ''Junimea'', a title which purposefully or unwittingly copied that of the influential [[Junimea|conservative association]] with whom he would later quarrel.<ref>Anghelescu, p.9; Vianu, Vol.II, p.346</ref> It was then that he met journalist and pedagogue [[Ștefan Velescu]], a meeting witnessed by Velescu's pupil, the future liberal journalist [[Constantin Bacalbașa]], who recorded it in his [[memoir]]s.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.345</ref> ''Oltul'' magazine, which he had helped establish and which displayed a liberal agenda, continued to be published until July 1875, and featured Macedonski's translations from [[Pierre-Jean de Béranger]], [[Hector de Charlieu]] and [[Alphonse de Lamartine]], as well as his debut in [[travel writing]] and short story.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.345, 419</ref> At age 22, he worked on his first play, a [[comedy]] titled ''Gemenii'' ("The Twins").<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.452">Vianu, Vol.II, p.452</ref> In 1874 that he came to the attention of young journalist future dramatist [[Ion Luca Caragiale]], who [[Satire|satirized]] him in articles for the magazine ''[[Ghimpele]]'', ridiculing his claim to Lithuanian descent, and eventually turning him into the character ''Aamsky'', whose fictional career ends with his death from exhaustion caused by contributing to "for the country's political development".<ref>Cioculescu, p.52-53</ref> This was the first episode in a consuming polemic between the two figures. Reflecting back on this period in 1892, Macedonski described Caragiale as a "noisy young man" of "[[Sophistry|sophistic]] reasoning", whose target audience was to be found in "[[beer garden]]s".<ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.177</ref>
===1875 trial and office as prefect=== [[File:Al. A. Macedonski 1878.JPG|thumb|1878 photograph of Macedonski]]
In March 1875, Macedonski was arrested on charges of [[defamation]]<ref>Călinescu, p.519; Sandqvist, p.197</ref> or [[sedition]].<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.347">Vianu, Vol.II, p.347</ref> For almost a year before, he and ''Oltul'' had taken an active part in the campaign against [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880–1918)|Conservative Party]] and its leader, [[Prime Minister of Romania|Premier]] [[Lascăr Catargiu]]. In this context, he had demanded that the common man "rise up with weapons in their hands and break both the government agents and the government", following up with similar messages aimed at the ''Domnitor''.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.346">Vianu, Vol.II, p.346</ref> He was taken to Bucharest's [[Văcărești prison]] and confined there for almost three months. Supported by the liberal press and defended by the most prestigious pro-liberal attorneys ([[Nicolae Fleva]] among them), Macedonski faced a jury trial on June 7, being eventually cleared of the charges.<ref>Călinescu, p.519; Vianu, Vol.II, p.347; Sandqvist, p.197. According to Vianu, the court also ruled out that Macedonski's arrest had been rendered void by the [[statute of limitations]].</ref> Reportedly, the Bucharest populace organized a spontaneous celebration of the verdict.<ref>Anghelescu, p.9; Călinescu, p.519; Vianu, Vol.II, p.347</ref>
In 1875, after the National Liberal [[Ion Emanuel Florescu]] was assigned the post of Premier by Carol, Macedonski embarked on an administrative career. The poet was upset by not being included on the National Liberal list for the [[Romanian general election, 1875|1875 suffrage]].<ref name="Călinescu, p.519; Vianu, Vol.II, p.347">Călinescu, p.519; Vianu, Vol.II, p.347</ref> This disenchantment led him into a brief conflict with the young liberal figure [[Bonifaciu Florescu]], only to join him soon afterward in editing ''Stindardul'' journal, alongside [[Pantazi Ghica]] and [[George Fălcoianu]].<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.347"/> The publication followed the line of [[Nicolae Moret Blaremberg]], made notorious for his [[Radicalism (historical)|radical]] and [[Republicanism|republican]] agenda.<ref name="Călinescu, p.519; Vianu, Vol.II, p.347"/> Ghica and Macedonski remained close friends until Ghica's 1882 death.<ref name="pippididilema">{{ro icon}} [[Andrei Pippidi]], [http://www.dilemaveche.ro/index.php?nr=164&cmd=articol&id=5331 "Acasă la Pantazi Ghica"], in ''[[Dilema Veche]]'', 164/IV, March 30, 2007</ref>
The new cabinet eventually appointed him [[Prefect (Romania)|Prefect]] of [[Bolgrad County|Bolgrad]] region, in the [[Budjak]] (at the time part of Romania). In parallel, he published his first translation, a version of ''[[Parisina]]'', an 1816 [[epic poem]] by [[George Gordon Byron, 6th Baron Byron|Lord Byron]],<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.349">Vianu, Vol.II, p.349</ref> and completed the original works ''Ithalo'' and ''Calul arabului'' ("The Arab's Horse").<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.347, 349</ref> He also spoke at the [[Romanian Atheneum]], presenting his views on the state of [[Literature of Romania|Romanian literature]] (1878).<ref>Anghelescu, p.9; Vianu, Vol.II, p.349-350</ref> His time in office ended upon the outbreak of the [[Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)|Russo-Turkish War]]. At the time, Russian volunteers were amassed on the Budjak border, requesting from the Romanian authorities the right of free passage into the [[Principality of Serbia]]. The National Liberal Premier [[Ion Brătianu]], who was negotiating an anti-[[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] alliance, sent Macedonski signals to let them pass, but the prefect, obeying the official recommendation of [[Ministry of Interior and Administrative Reform (Romania)|Internal Affairs Minister]] [[George D. Vernescu]], decided against it, and was consequently stripped of his office.<ref name="Călinescu, p.519" />
Still determined to pursue a career in the press, Macedonski founded a string of unsuccessful magazines with [[Patriotism|patriotic]] content and titles such as ''Vestea'' ("The Announcement"), ''Dunărea'' ("The [[Danube]]"), ''Fulgerul'' ("The Lightning") and, after 1880, ''Tarara'' (an [[onomatopoeia]] equivalent to "Toodoodoo").<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.348, 350-351</ref> Their history is connected with that of the Russo-Turkish War, at the end of which Romanian participation on the Russian side resulted in her independence.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.348">Vianu, Vol.II, p.348</ref> Macedonski remained committed to the anti-Ottoman cause, and, some thirty years later, stated: "We want no [[Rumelia|Turkey in Europe]]!"<ref name="elrseisl">{{ro icon}} [[Eugen Lungu]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20080820172941/http://www.sud-est.md/numere/20020709 "Islamul la noi acasă. Monologul lui Baiazid"], in ''[[Revista Sud-Est]]'', Nr. 2 (48)/2002</ref>
By 1879, the poet, who continued to voice criticism of Carol, had several times switched sides between the National Liberals and the opposition Conservatives.<ref name="Călinescu, p.519" /> That year, while the Budjak was ceded to Russia and [[Northern Dobruja]] was integrated into Romania, the Brătianu cabinet appointed him administrator of the [[Sulina]] ''[[plasă]]'' and the [[Danube Delta]]. He had previously refused to be made [[comptroller]] in [[Putna County]], believing such an appointment to be beneath his capacity, and had lost a National Liberal appointment in [[Silistra]] when [[Southern Dobruja]] was granted to the [[Principality of Bulgaria]].<ref name="Călinescu, p.519" /> During this short interval in office, he traveled to the [[Snake Island (Black Sea)|Snake Island]] in the [[Black Sea]]—his appreciation for the place later motivated him to write the [[Fantasy literature|fantasy novel]] ''[[Thalassa, Le Calvaire de feu]]'' and the poem ''Lewki''.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.348-349</ref>
===Early ''Literatorul'' years=== With the 1880s came a turning point in Alexandru Macedonski's career. Vianu notes that changes took place in the poet's relationship with his public: "Society recognizes in him the nonconformist. [...] The man becomes singular; people start talking about his oddities."<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.350</ref> Macedonski's presumed frustration at being perceived in this way, Vianu notes, may have led him closer to the idea of ''[[poète maudit]]'', theorized earlier by [[Paul Verlaine]].<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.350, 360-361</ref> In this context, he had set his sight on promoting "social poetry", the merger between [[lyricism]] and political militantism.<ref>Călinescu, p.515-516, 523; Vianu, Vol.II, p.343, 351</ref> Meanwhile, according to Călinescu, his attacks on the liberals and the "daft insults he aimed at [Romania's] throne" had effectively ruined his own chance of political advancement.<ref name="Călinescu, p.519" />
In January 1880, he launched his most influential and long-lived publication, ''[[Literatorul]]'', which was also the focal point of his [[Eclecticism|eclectic]] cultural circle, and, in later years, of the [[Symbolist movement in Romania|local Symbolist school]]. In its first version, the magazine was co-edited by Macedonski, Bonifaciu Florescu and poet [[Th. M. Stoenescu]].<ref>Ornea, p.301; Vianu, Vol.II, p.351</ref> Florescu parted with the group soon after, due to a disagreement with Macedonski, and was later attacked by the latter for allegedly accumulating academic posts.<ref name="Călinescu, p.529">Călinescu, p.529</ref> ''Literatorul'' aimed to irritate ''Junimist'' sensibilities from its first issue, when it stated its dislike for "political prejudice in literature."<ref>Ornea, p.301</ref> This was most likely an allusion to the views of ''Junimist'' figure [[Titu Maiorescu]], being later accompanied by explicit attacks on him and his followers.<ref>Ornea, p.301-302</ref> An early success for the new journal was the warm reception it received from [[Vasile Alecsandri]], a Romantic poet and occasional ''Junimist'' whom Macedonski idolized at the time, and the collaboration of popular memoirist [[Gheorghe Sion]].<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.351">Vianu, Vol.II, p.351</ref> Another such figure was the intellectual [[V. A. Urechia]], whom Macedonski made president of the ''Literatorul'' Society.<ref>Anghelescu, p.10; Călinescu, p.529; Vianu, Vol.II, p.351</ref> In 1881, [[Ministry of Education, Research and Youth (Romania)|Education Minister]] Urechia granted Macedonski the ''Bene-Merenti'' medal 1st class,<ref>Anghelescu, p.10; Călinescu, p.519; Sandqvist, p.197</ref> although, Călinescu stresses, the poet had only totaled 18 months of public service.<ref name="Călinescu, p.519" /> At around that time, Macedonski had allegedly begun courting actress [[Aristizza Romanescu]], who rejected his advances, leaving him unenthusiastic about love matters and unwilling to seek female company.<ref>Nastasă, p.94, 97-98, 106</ref>
[[File:Alexandru Macedonski - prima pagina - Poesii.png|thumb|First page of ''[[Poezii (Macedonski)|Poesii]]'', 1882]] In parallel, Macedonski used the magazine to publicize his disagreement with the main ''Junimist'' voice, ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]''. Among the group of contributors, several had already been victims of Maiorescu's irony: Sion, Urechia, Pantazi Ghica and [[Petru Grădișteanu]].<ref>Ornea, p.302-303</ref> While welcoming the debut of its contributor, [[Parnassianism|Parnassian]]-[[Neoclassicism|Neoclassicist]] novelist and poet [[Duiliu Zamfirescu]],<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.351"/> Macedonski repeatedly attacked its main exponent, the conservative poet Eminescu, claiming not to understand his poetry.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.353-355. According to Vianu (Vol.II, p.355), [[Duiliu Zamfirescu]] also joined in the attack, using ''Literatorul'' for articles where his rival Eminescu was being criticized on various grounds, and signing them with the pseudonym ''Rienzi''.</ref> However, ''Literatorul'' was also open to contributions from some ''Convorbiri Literare'' affiliates (Zamfirescu, [[Matilda Cugler-Poni]] and [[Veronica Micle]]).<ref>Ornea, p.303</ref>
In November 1880, Macedonski's plays ''Iadeș!'' ("Wishbone!", a comedy first printed in 1882) and ''Unchiașul Sărăcie'' ("Old Man Poverty") premiered at the [[National Theater Bucharest]].<ref>Anghelescu, p.10; Vianu, Vol.II, p.351, 452</ref> A sign of government approval, this was followed by Macedonski's appointment to a minor administrative office, as Historical Monuments Inspector.<ref>Călinescu, p.519; Sandqvist, p.197; Vianu, Vol.II, p.351, 361</ref> Nevertheless, both plays failed to impose themselves on public perception, and were withdrawn from the program by 1888.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.462">Vianu, Vol.II, p.462</ref> Călinescu asserts that, although Macedonski later claimed to have always been facing poverty, his job in the administration, coupled with other sources of revenue, ensured him a comfortable existence.<ref>Călinescu, p.519-520</ref>
In 1881, Macedonski published a new collection of poetry. Titled ''[[Poezii (Macedonski)|Poezii]]'', it carries the year "1882" on its original cover.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.351, 394</ref> Again moving away from liberalism, Macedonski sought to make himself accepted by ''Junimea'' and Maiorescu.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.356-357</ref> He consequently attended the ''Junimea'' sessions, and gave a public reading of ''Noaptea de noiembrie'' ("November Night"), the first publicized piece in his lifelong ''[[Nights (Macedonski)|Nights]]'' cycle.<ref>Anghelescu, p.10; Ornea, p.304-305; Vianu, Vol.I, p.54; Vol.II, p.356</ref> It reportedly earned him the praise of historian and poet [[Bogdan Petriceicu Hasdeu]], who, although an anti-''Junimist'', happened to be in the audience.<ref>Anghelescu, p.16; Vianu, Vol.I, p.54</ref> Despite rumors according to which he had applauded Macedonski, Maiorescu himself was not impressed, and left an unenthusiastic account of the event in his private diary.<ref>Anghelescu, p.16; Perpessicius, p.246; Ornea, p.304</ref>
===Against Alecsandri and Eminescu=== Macedonski's open conflict with ''Junimea'' began in 1882, when he engaged in a publicized polemic with Alecsandri.<ref>Anghelescu, p.10; Călinescu, p.296; Vianu, Vol.II, p.350-352</ref> It was ignited when, through Macedonski's articles, ''Literatorul'' criticized Alecsandri for accepting [[Romanian Academy]] prizes despite being its member,<ref>Anghelescu, p.10; Călinescu, p.296; Vianu, Vol.II, p.351-352</ref> and later involved Sion (whose replies on behalf of the Academy were derided by Macedonski).<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.351-352</ref> Macedonski also took distance from Alecsandri's style, publishing a "critical analysis" of his poetry in one issue of ''Literatorul''.<ref>Anghelescu, p.10</ref> In turn, Alecsandri humiliated his young rival by portraying him as [[Zoilus]], the prototype of slanderers, and himself as the model poet [[Horace]] in the 1883 play ''[[Fântâna Blanduziei]]''.<ref>Călinescu, p.316; Vianu, Vol.II, p.352-353</ref> The two were eventually reconciled, and Macedonski again spoke of Alecsandri as his ideological and stylistic predecessor.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.353">Vianu, Vol.II, p.353</ref>
In April 1882, Eminescu had also replied to Macedonski in ''[[Timpul]]'' journal, referring to an unnamed poet who "barely finishes high-school, comes over to Bucharest selling nick-nacks and makeup [and goes into] literary dealership". Reproaching Macedonski's attacks on Alecsandri, Eminescu makes a [[nationalism|nationalist]] comment about the young poet bearing "the bastard instincts of those foreigners who were [[Romanianization|Romanianized]] only yesterday", and attributes him "the physiognomy of a hairdresser".<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.357. Vianu believes that Macedonski had not authored any of the anti-Eminescu articles before that date.</ref> Through the articles of [[Petru Th. Missir]], ''Convorbiri Literare'' gave ''Poezii'' a negative review, deemed "malevolent" by literary historian [[Mircea Anghelescu]].<ref name="Anghelescu, p.15">Anghelescu, p.15</ref> At the other end of the political and cultural spectrum, Macedonski faced opposition from the intellectuals attracted to [[socialism]], in particular ''[[Contemporanul]]'' editors [[Constantin Mille]] and [[Ioan Nădejde]], with whom he was engaged in an extended polemic.<ref>Anghelescu, p.15; Perpessicus, p.138-139, 266, 352</ref>
In the meantime, Macedonski published his own play, which had Cuza for its main character and was eponymously titled ''Cuza-Vodă'',<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.462"/> and completed translations for ''Literatorul''—from [[Maurice Rollinat]], whom he helped impose as a main cultural reference in Romanian Symbolism, and from the [[Greeks|Greek]] poet [[Akhillefs Paraskhos]].<ref>Vianu, Vol.I, p.296-299; Vol.III, p.385-386</ref> In 1883, he also contributed his first [[sketch story]], ''Casa cu nr. 10'' ("The House at Number 10").<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.420-421</ref> In early 1883, he married Ana Rallet-Slătineanu.<ref>Anghelescu, p.10; Călinescu, p.519; Nastasă, p.106; Vianu, Vol.II, p.353</ref> Wealthy and supposedly related to Romanian aristocrats,<ref>Călinescu, p.519; Nastasă, p.106-107</ref> she would bear him five children in all: the painter [[Alexis Macedonski|Alexis]] was the eldest, followed by Nikita; the three youngest were two sons (Panel and Constantin Macedonski) and a daughter, Anna (also known as Nina).<ref>Călinescu, p.522</ref> His heterosexual lifestyle notwithstanding, Macedonski remained a self-avowed admirer of male beauties, and was rumored to be a closeted homosexual.<ref name="mzrivalul"/>
In July 1883, Macedonski undertook one of his most controversial anti-''Junimist'' actions. That month, ''Literatorul'' published an [[epigram]] signed with the pseudonym ''Duna'',<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.353"/> deriding an unnamed author who had lost his mind. Mihai Eminescu—whom many had already come to see as Romania's [[List of national poets|national poet]]—had by then developed a [[mental disorder]] which had become known to the general public. Ever since that moment, Macedonski has generally been believed to be ''Duna'', and as a result, was faced with much criticism from both readers and commentators.<ref name="vztcron"/><ref name="mzrivalul"/><ref>Anghelescu, p.10; Călinescu, p.519, 520-521; Cernat, p.10; Perpessicius, p.138-139, 266, 352; Vianu, Vol.II, p.353-361, 387</ref> The intense anti-''Literatorul'' press campaign was initiated in August, when writer [[Grigore Ventura]] issued an article condemning Macedonski's attitude (published in the Bucharest-based newspaper ''[[L'Indépendance Roumaine]]''), with Macedonski responding in the National Liberal organ ''[[Românul]]''.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.358-360</ref> During one evening, Macedonski is reported to have been assaulted by anonymous supporters of Eminescu.<ref>Călinescu, p.520; Vianu, Vol.II, p.359</ref> His previous conflict with Nădejde was also affected by this renewed controversy: while opposed to ''Junimist'' policies, the socialists at ''Contemporanul'' voiced their admiration for Eminescu's art.<ref>Perpessicus, p.138-139, 266, 352</ref>
Late in 1883, Macedonski and his friends unveiled [[Ion Georgescu]]'s statue of their mentor Bolintineanu in the National Theater lobby. The circumstances in which this took place rose suspicion of foul play; on this grounds, Macedonski was ridiculed by his former friend Zamfirescu in the journal ''[[România Liberă]]'', which left him embittered.<ref>Călinescu, p.533; Vianu, Vol.II, p.353-354, 391</ref> Călinescu proposes that, although such negative reactions were invoked by Macedonski's supporters as a sign of their mentor having been marginalized, Macedonski had expressed his dissatisfaction with the cultural environment long before that moment, and was still a respected figure even after the incidents took place.<ref>Călinescu, p.519-520, 521</ref>
===First Paris sojourn and ''Poezia viitorului''=== [[File:Le Vaisseau fantôme Macedonski L'Élan littéraire.PNG|thumb|260px|Macedonski's poem ''Le Vaisseau fantôme'' ("The Phantom Ship"), as originally published in ''[[L'Élan littéraire]]'' (February 1885)]]
Having been stripped of his administrative office by the new Brătianu cabinet,<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.360-361</ref> Macedonski faced financial difficulties, and was forced to move into a house on the outskirts of Bucharest, and later moved between houses in northern Bucharest.<ref>Călinescu, p.520-521, 523</ref> According to Călinescu, the poet continued to cultivate luxury and passionately invested in the [[decorative arts]], although his source of income, other than the supposed assistance "of [European] ruling houses", remains a mystery.<ref>Călinescu, p.522-523</ref> Arguing that Macedonski was "always in need of money" to use on his luxury items, poet [[Victor Eftimiu]] claimed: "He did not shy away from sending emphatic notes to the potentates of his day [...], flattering some, threatening others. He would marry off or simply mate some of his disciples with aging and rich women, and then he would squeeze out their assets."<ref name="veready">{{ro icon}} [http://www.dilemaveche.ro/index.php?nr=154&cmd=articol&id=4780 "Ready Made"], in ''[[Dilema Veche]]'', Vol. IV, Nr. 154, January 2007</ref>
Macedonski eventually left Romania in 1884, visiting [[Paris]]. On his way there, he passed through Craiova, where he met aspiring author [[Traian Demetrescu]], whose works he had already hosted in ''Literatorul'' and who was to become his friend and protégé. Demetrescu later recalled being gripped by "tremors of emotion" upon first catching sight of Macedonski.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.361">Vianu, Vol.II, p.361</ref> In France, Macedonski set up contacts within the French literary environment, and began contributing to French or [[Francophone]] literary publications—including the Belgian Symbolist platforms ''[[La Wallonie]]'' and ''[[L'Élan littéraire]]''.<ref>Cernat, p.12; Sandqvist, p.197; Suciu, p.104, 109; Vianu, Vol.II, p.362; Vida, p.55</ref> His collaboration with ''La Wallonie'' alongside [[Albert Mockel]], Tudor Vianu believes, makes Alexandru Macedonski one in the original wave of European Symbolists.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.362. Krasztev (''From a Deadlocked Present...'', p.42) considers Macedonski "the first [[East Central Europe]]an symbolist poet".</ref> This adaptation to Symbolism also drew on his marked [[Francophile|Francophilia]], which in turn complemented his tendencies toward [[cosmopolitanism]].<ref name="mzrivalul"/><ref>Cernat, p.10, 18; Suciu, p.102, 103-110; Vianu, Vol.II, p.362. See also Boia, p.190, 245</ref> He became opposed to Carol I, who, in 1881, had been granted the [[King of Romania|Crown]] of the [[Kingdom of Romania|Romanian Kingdom]]. In addition to his admiration for Cuza and the [[Wallachian Revolution of 1848|1848 Wallachian revolutionaries]], the poet objected to the King's sympathy for France's main rival, the [[German Empire]].<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.363, 366</ref> In January 1885, after having returned from the voyage, he announced his retirement from public life, claiming that German influence and its exponents at ''Junimea'' had "conquered" [[Culture of Romania|Romanian culture]],<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.362</ref> and repeating his claim that Eminescu lacked value.<ref name="Călinescu, p.521">Călinescu, p.521</ref>
In the meantime, ''Literatorul'' went out of print, although new series were still published at irregular intervals until 1904 (when it ceased being published altogether).<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.362-363, 365, 366-367, 371-372, 376</ref> The magazine was reportedly hated by the public, causing Macedonski, Stoenescu, Florescu, Urechia and educator [[Anghel Demetriescu]] to try to revive it as ''Revista Literară'' ("The Literary Review", published for a few months in 1885).<ref>Călinescu, p.516, 520; Vianu, Vol.II, p.363</ref> The poet attempted to establish other magazines, all of them short-lived, and, in 1887, handed for print his [[Naturalism (literature)|Naturalist]] [[novella]] ''Dramă banală'' ("Banal Drama")<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.421">Vianu, Vol.II, p.421</ref> while completing one of the most revered episodes in the ''Nights'' series, ''Noaptea de mai'' ("May Night").<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.363">Vianu, Vol.II, p.363</ref> Also in 1886, he worked on his other Naturalist novellas: ''Zi de august'' ("August Day"), ''Pe drum de poștă'' ("On the Stagecoach Trail"), ''Din carnetul unui dezertor'' ("From the Notebook of a Deserter"), ''Între cotețe'' ("Amidst Hen Houses") and the eponymous ''Nicu Dereanu''.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.421"/>
By 1888, he was again sympathetic toward Blaremberg, whose dissident National Liberal faction had formed an alliance with the Conservatives, editing ''Stindardul Țărei'' (later ''Straja Țărei'') as his supporting journal.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.364-365</ref> However, late in the same year, he returned to the liberal mainstream, being assigned a weekly column in ''Românul'' newspaper.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.365">Vianu, Vol.II, p.365</ref> Two years later, he attempted to relaunch ''Literatorul'' under the leadership of liberal figure [[Bogdan Petriceicu Hasdeu]], but the latter eventually settled for founding his own ''[[Revista Nouă]]''.<ref>Anghelescu, p.11</ref> Around 1891, he saluted ''Junimea''{{'}}s own break with the Conservatives and its entry into politics at the Conservative-Constitutional Party, before offering an enthusiastic welcome to the 1892 ''Junimist'' agitation among university students.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.365"/> In 1894, he would speak in front of student crowds gathered at a political rally in [[University Square, Bucharest|University Square]], and soon after made himself known for supporting the cause of [[Romanians|ethnic Romanians]] and other underrepresented groups of [[Austria-Hungary]].<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.367">Vianu, Vol.II, p.367</ref>
His literary thesis of the time was titled ''Poezia viitorului'' ("The Poetry of the Future"). It upheld Symbolist authors as the models to follow,<ref>Anghelescu, p.11; Cioculescu, p.63; Răileanu & Carassou, p.152; Sandqvist, p.199, 382; Suciu, p.109-110; Vianu, Vol.II, p.366</ref> while Macedonski personally began producing what he referred to as "instrumentalist" poems, composed around musical and [[Onomatopoeia|onomatopoeic]] elements, and showing a preference for [[internal rhyme]]s.<ref>Călinescu, p.525-526; Vianu, Vol.II, p.365, 414-418. See also Vida, p.55</ref> Such an [[experimental literature|experimental]] approach was soon after [[Parody|parodied]] and ridiculed by Ion Luca Caragiale, who had by then affiliated and parted with ''Junimea'', in his new ''[[Moftul Român]]'' magazine.<ref>Anghelescu, p.11; Cioculescu, p.63-64, 67, 134; Vianu, Vol.II, p.366, 373</ref> The poet sought to reconcile with his rival, publicizing a claim that Caragiale was being unjustly ignored by the cultural establishment, but this attempt failed to mend relations between them, and the conflict escalated further.<ref>Cioculescu, p.135</ref>
While, in 1893, ''Literatorul'' hosted fragments of ''Thalassa'' in its [[Romanian-language]] version,<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.436">Vianu, Vol.II, p.436</ref><ref name="cmmareroman">{{ro icon}} Cornel Moraru, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Un-mare-roman-simbolist*articleID_4226-articles_details.html "Un mare roman simbolist"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 41, December 2000</ref> the author also launched a daily, ''Lumina'' ("The Light").<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.367"/> It was also at that stage that Alexandru Macedonski associated with [[Cincinat Pavelescu]], the noted epigrammarian, who joined him in editing ''Literatorul'', and with whom he co-authored the 1893 verse [[tragedy]] depicting the [[Bible|Biblical]] hero [[Saul]], and named after him. Although showcased by the National Theater with star actor [[Constantin Nottara]] in the title role, it failed to register success with the public.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.366-367, 465-466</ref> Two years later, the two ''Literatorul'' editors made headlines as pioneers of [[cycling]]. An enthusiastic promoter of the sport, Macedonski joined fellow poet [[Constantin Cantilli]] on a marathon, pedaling from Bucharest across the border into Austria-Hungary, all the way down to [[Brașov]].<ref>Călinescu, p.522; Vianu, Vol.II, p.367</ref>
===Late 1890s=== Macedonski also returned with a new volume of poetry, ''[[Excelsior (Macedonski)|Excelsior]]'' (consecutive editions in 1895 and 1896),<ref>Anghelescu, p.11, 12; Vianu, Vol.II, p.364, 367-368</ref> and founded ''Liga Ortodoxă'' ("The Orthodox League"), a magazine noted for hosting the debut of [[Tudor Arghezi]], later one of the most celebrated figures in Romanian literature.<ref>Anghelescu, p.11; Călinescu, p.808; Cernat, p.8, 29; Vianu, Vol.II, p.368-369; Vol.III, p.280, 476-478</ref> Macedonski commended his new protégé for reaching "the summit of poetry and art" at "an age when I was still prattling verses".<ref>Vianu, Vol.III, p.477</ref> ''Liga Ortodoxă'' also hosted articles against Caragiale, which Macedonski signed with the pseudonym ''Sallustiu'' ("[[Sallustius]]").<ref>Cioculescu, p.135, 136</ref> The magazine was additional proof of Macedonski's return to conservatism, and largely dedicated to defending the cause of [[Patriarch of All Romania|Romanian Orthodox Metropolitan]] [[Ghenadie Petrescu|Ghenadie]], deposed by the [[Romanian Synod]] following a political scandal. It defended Ghenadie up until he chose to resign, and subsequently went out of print.<ref>Anghelescu, p.11; Vianu, Vol.II, p.368-369, 371</ref> Macedonski was shocked to note that Ghenadie had given up his own defense.<ref name="igpresa">{{ro icon}} Ion Georgescu, [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/vestitorul/1937/BCUCLUJ_FP_279921_1937_013_004.pdf "Presa periodică și publiciștii români"], in ''Vestitorul'', Nr. 4/1937, p.41 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref>
In 1895, his ''Casa cu nr. 10'' was translated into French by the ''[[Journal des Débats]]'', whose editors reportedly found it [[picturesque]].<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.421"/> Two years later, Macedonski himself published French-language translations of his earlier poetry under the title ''Bronzes'', a volume prefaced by his disciple, the critic and promoter [[Alexandru Bogdan-Pitești]].<ref>Boia, p.190-191, 245; Cernat, p.12, 42; Vianu, Vol.II, p.369-370. See also Suciu, p.107</ref> Although it was positively reviewed by ''[[Mercure de France]]'' magazine,<ref>Răileanu & Carassou, p.152; Vianu, Vol.II, p.371</ref> ''Bronzes'' was largely unnoticed by the French audience, a fact which Tudor Vianu attributes to Bogdan-Pitești's lack of qualification for the cultural mission Macedonski had trusted him with.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.370-371</ref> By that time, his circle had come to be frequented with regularity by Bogdan-Pitești's friend and collaborator, the celebrated painter [[Ștefan Luchian]], who was in the Symbolist and [[Art Nouveau]] stage of his career.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Pavel Șușară]], [http://www.romlit.ro/index.pl/tefan_luchian "Ștefan Luchian"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 4/2006</ref>
{{multiple image | align = right | image1 = Alexandru Macedonski - prima pagina - Excelsior.jpg | width1 = 230 | caption1 = First page of ''[[Excelsior (Macedonski)|Excelsior]]'', 1895 | image2 = Alexandru Macedonski - prima pagina - Cartea de aur.JPG | width2 = 230 | caption2 = First page of ''Cartea de aur'', 1902 }} By 1898, Macedonski was again facing financial difficulties, and his collaborators resorted to organizing a [[fundraiser]] in his honor.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.371">Vianu, Vol.II, p.371</ref> His rejection of the Orthodox establishment was documented by his political tract, published that year as ''{{lang|ro|Falimentul clerului ortodox}}''.<ref name="igpresa"/> Between that time and 1900, he focused on researching [[Esotericism|esoteric]], [[occult]] and [[Pseudoscience|pseudoscientific]] subjects.<ref>Călinescu, p.523; Cernat, p.11; Vianu, Vol.II, p.372-373, 386</ref> [[Traian Demetrescu]], who recorded his visits with Macedonski, recalled his former mentor being opposed to his [[Positivism|positivist]] take on science, claiming to explain the workings of the Universe in "a different way", through "imagination", but also taking an interest in [[Camille Flammarion]]'s [[astronomy]] studies.<ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.389</ref> Macedonski was determined to interpret death through [[Parapsychology|parapsychological]] means, and, in 1900, conferenced at the Atheneum on the subject ''Sufletul și viața viitoare'' ("The Soul and the Coming Life").<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.372</ref> The focal point of his vision was that man could voluntarily stave off death with words and gestures, a concept he elaborated upon in his later articles.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.372-373, 386</ref> In one such piece, Macedonski argued: "man has the power [...] to compact the energy currents known as thoughts to the point where he changes them, according to his own will, into objects or soul-bearing creatures."<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.386</ref> He also attempted to build a machine for extinguishing [[chimney fire]]s.<ref name="Călinescu, p.523">Călinescu, p.523</ref> Later, Nikita Macedonski registered the invention of [[nacre]]-treated paper, which is sometimes attributed to his father.<ref name="veready"/><ref>Călinescu, p.523; Răileanu & Carassou, p.152</ref>
===Caion scandal and expatriation=== The few issues of ''Literatorul'' that were printed in 1899-1900 saw the circle being joined by the young Symbolist poet [[Ștefan Petică]].<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.371"/> In 1902, he published ''Cartea de aur'' ("The Golden Book"), comprising his [[Sketch story|sketch stories]] and novellas. In parallel, Macedonski returned to the public scene, founding ''[[Forța Morală]]'' magazine. It was through this venue that he began responding to Ion Luca Caragiale's earlier attacks.<ref>Anghelescu, p.12; Cioculescu, p.132-140; Vianu, Vol. II, p.373-376</ref> This he did by hosting the articles of aspiring journalist [[Constantin Al. Ionescu-Caion]], who accused Caragiale of having [[Plagiarism|plagiarized]] a [[Hungary|Hungarian]] author by the name of Kemény in his tragedy play ''[[Năpasta]]''. Kemény turned out to be non-existent.<ref>Cioculescu, p.140; Vianu, Vol. II, p.373-376</ref> According to Vianu, Macedonski had no prior knowledge of the fraud, but had also been "blinded" by his resentments instead of displaying "discernment", and had even showed evidence of "insanity".<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.373, 387</ref> Most in Macedonski's own series of anti-Caragiale articles were unsigned, or signed with pseudonyms such as ''Luciliu'' ("[[Gaius Lucilius]]").<ref>Cioculescu, p.134-136</ref>
Like in the case of Eminescu's conflict with Macedonski, the polemic enlisted a negative response from the public.<ref>According to Anghelescu (p.12), Cioculescu (p.137) and Vianu (Vol. II, p.374), Macedonski was [[Heckler|heckled]] by the public during a conference at the [[Romanian Atheneum]], and responded by blowing a whisle. Călinescu (p.493) recounts the same story with Caragiale for a protagonist.</ref> The poet's associate [[Th. M. Stoenescu]] convinced himself that Caragiale was being framed, and refused to allow ''Revista Literară'' to be used for endorsing Caion, which caused Macedonski to shun him.<ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.374, 391</ref> Macedonski refused to withdraw his support for the cause even after Caragiale sued Caion, but ''Forța Morală'' soon went out of print.<ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.374-376</ref> Before it did so, the journal hosted some of Macedonski's most renowned poems, including ''Lewki'' and ''Noaptea de decemvrie'' ("December Night"),<ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.375-376</ref> together with his article on [[Remy de Gourmont]]'s thoughts on [[poetics]].<ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.413-414</ref>
In his article of 1903, titled ''{{lang|ro|Spre ocultism. Orientări ulterioare spre teozofie și filozofie socială}}'' ("Toward Occultism. Later Orientations toward [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|Theosophy]] and [[Social Philosophy]]"), the poet envisaged making his interest in esoteric subjects the basis of a new literary movement.<ref name="Cernat, p.11">Cernat, p.11</ref> Also that year, poet [[George Bacovia]] began attending the literary circle, and gave a reading of his celebrated ''[[Plumb (Bacovia)|Plumb]]'' poem, being welcomed by Macedonski with a flattering epigram.<ref name="Anghelescu, p.12">Anghelescu, p.12</ref> Macedonski's series of short-lived periodicals resumed in 1905, when he founded ''Le Beau Danube Bleu'' (French for "The Beautiful Blue Danube") and ''Liga Conservatoare'' ("The Conservative League").<ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.376-377</ref> He registered more success in 1906, when his ''Thalassa'' was published, as ''Le Calvaire de feu'', by [[Edward Sansot]]'s Paris-based publishing house.<ref name="cmmareroman"/><ref>Anghelescu, p.12; Boia, p.245; Sandqvist, p.383; Vianu, Vol.II, p.371, 377, 436-440</ref> This followed intense self-promotion within the French literary environment, as well as advertisements in the French press.<ref name="mzrivalul"/><ref>Sandqvist, p.197; Vianu, Vol. II, p.376-377</ref> Part of this involved Macedonski sending his book to be reviewed by [[Émile Faguet]], [[Jean Mounet-Sully]], [[Joséphin Péladan]], [[Pierre Quillard]] and [[Jean Richepin]], who replied with what Vianu deems "the politeness of circumstance."<ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.377. See also Suciu, p.104</ref> The volume was nonetheless favorably reviewed by the prestigious magazines ''Mercure de France'' and ''[[Gil Blas (periodical)|Gil Blas]]''.<ref name="Vianu, Vol. II, p.438-439">Vianu, Vol. II, p.438-439</ref>
Also in 1906, ''[[La Revue Musicale]]'' published his interview with Combarieu, through which the latter aimed to verify supposed connections between literary inspiration and musical sensitivity.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.341</ref> By 1907, he was concentrating on experiments in physics, and eventually publicized his claim to have discovered that light does not travel through [[vacuum]].<ref>Anghelescu, p.12; Călinescu, p.523; Vianu, Vol.II, p.377-378</ref> He sent a paper on astronomy subjects to be reviewed by the [[Société Astronomique de France]], of which he subsequently became a member.<ref name="Anghelescu, p.12"/> The same year, he drafted the plan for a [[world government]], announcing that he had found sympathy for the cause throughout Europe.<ref name="Călinescu, p.523"/> Macedonski also introduced himself to an [[Italophone]] public, when two of his [[sonnet]]s were published by ''[[Poezia (magazine)|Poesia]]'', the magazine of [[Futurism|Futurist]] theorist [[Filippo Tommaso Marinetti]].<ref>Cernat, p.88-89; Sandqvist, p.200, 235, 383. Cernat gives the date as 1909, while Sandqvist mentions 1895 and 1899.</ref>
Between 1910 and 1912, Macedonski was again in Paris.<ref>Anghelescu, p.12-13; Călinescu, p.522; Vianu, Vol.II, p.377-379; Vol.III, p.352</ref> Seeking to withdraw himself from Romania's public life due to what he perceived as injustice,<ref name="Vianu, Vol.III, p.352">Vianu, Vol.III, p.352</ref> he had by then completed work on the French-language [[tragicomedy]] ''Le Fou?'' ("The Madman?"), which was only published after his death.<ref name="mzrivalul"/><ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.378-379</ref> He was actively seeking to establish his reputation in [[Theatre of France|French theater]], reading his new play to a circle which included [[Louis de Gonzague Frick]] and [[Florian-Parmentier]], while, at home, newspapers reported rumors that his work was going to be staged by [[Sarah Bernhardt]]'s company.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.378-379, 467</ref> His efforts were largely fruitless, and, accompanied by his son Alexis, the poet left France, spent some time in Italy, and eventually returned to Romania.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.379">Vianu, Vol.II, p.379</ref> Passing through the [[German Empire]], he learned of Ion Luca Caragiale's sudden death, and wrote ''[[Adevărul]]'' daily an [[open letter]], which showed that he had come to revise his stance, notably comparing the deceased author's style and legacy to those of [[Mark Twain]].<ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.374-375</ref>
During Macedonski's absence, his style and work had come to be reviewed more positively, in particular by the young authors [[I. Dragoslav]], [[Horia Furtună]], [[Ion Pillat]], [[Anastasie Mândru]], [[Al. T. Stamatiad]], as well as by post-''Junimist'' critic [[Mihail Dragomirescu]], who offered Macedonski a good reception in his ''[[Convorbiri Critice]]'' magazine.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.379-380; Vol.III, p.350-353</ref> Tudor Vianu, who cites contemporary statements by Dragoslav, concludes that, upon arrival, Macedonski was enthusiastically received by a public who had missed him.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.379"/> Also in 1912, one of his poems was published as an homage by ''[[Simbolul]]'', a magazine published by the young and radical Symbolists [[Tristan Tzara]], [[Ion Vinea]] and [[Marcel Janco]].<ref>Cernat, p.49; Sandqvist, p.75, 384</ref> Around that time, Macedonski also collaborated with the [[Iași]]-based moderate Symbolist magazine ''[[Versuri și Proză]]''.<ref>Călinescu, p.684; Cernat, p.55</ref> Polemics surrounding his case nevertheless continued: in late 1912, as part of a National Theater adaptation of [[Alphonse Daudet]]'s ''[[Sapho (novel)|Sapho]]'', actor [[Cazimir Belcot]] borrowed from Macedonski's appearance and mannerisms to portray a failure.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.381">Vianu, Vol.II, p.381</ref>
===Return and World War I years=== Macedonski and his protégés had become regular frequenters of Bucharest cafés. Having a table permanently reserved for him at Imperial Hotel's [[Kübler Coffeehouse]],<ref name="vztcron" /><ref>Sandqvist, p.118, 120, 199</ref> he was later a presence in two other such establishments: High-Life<ref name="vztcron" /><ref>Sandqvist, p.120</ref> and [[Terasa Oteteleșanu]].<ref name="micafene">Mioara Ioniță, "Cafenele de altădată. Terasa Oteteleșanu", in ''[[Magazin Istoric]]'', October 2003</ref> He is said to have spent part of his time at Kübler loudly mocking the traditionalist poets who gathered at an opposite table.<ref>Sandqvist, p.199</ref> Meanwhile, the poet's literary club, set up at his house in [[Dorobanți]] quarter, had come to resemble a [[Mysticism|mystical]] circle, over which he held magisterial command. Vianu, who visited the poet together with Pillat, compares this atmosphere with those created by other "mystics and magi of poetry" (citing as examples [[Joséphin Péladan]], [[Louis-Nicolas Ménard]], [[Stéphane Mallarmé]] and [[Stefan George]]).<ref name="Vianu, Vol.III, p.352"/> The hall where seances were hosted was only lit by candles, and the tables were covered in red fabric.<ref name="vztcron" /><ref>Călinescu, p.523; Vianu, Vol.III, p.352</ref> Macedonski himself was seated on a throne designed by Alexis, and adopted a dominant pose.<ref name="vztcron" /><ref>Călinescu, p.522-523; Sandqvist, p.25, 199</ref> The apparent secrecy and the [[initiation rite]]s performed on new members were purportedly inspired by [[Rosicrucianism]] and the [[Freemasonry]].<ref>Krasztev, "From a Deadlocked Present...", p.42-43; Sandqvist, p.199-200</ref> By then, Macedonski was rewarding his followers' poems with false [[gemstone]]s.<ref>Călinescu, p.523; Cernat, p.43; Răileanu & Carassou, p.152; Sandqvist, p.25, 200</ref>
The poet founded ''Revista Critică'' ("The Critical Review"), which again closed after a short while, and issued the poetry volume ''[[Flori sacre]]'' ("Sacred Flowers").<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.380-381</ref> Grouping his ''Forța Morală'' poems and older pieces, it was dedicated to his new generation of followers, whom Macedonski's preface referred to as "the new Romania."<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.380</ref> He continued to hope that ''Le Fou?'' was going to be staged in France, especially after he received some encouragement in the form of articles in ''Mercure de France'' and ''Journal des Débats'', but was confronted with the general public's indifference.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.381"/> In 1914, ''Thalassa'' was published in a non-definitive version by [[Constantin Banu]]'s magazine ''[[Flacăra]]'',<ref name="cmmareroman"/><ref>Anghelescu, p.13; Vianu, Vol.II, p.382, 440; Vol.III, p.353</ref> which sought to revive overall interest in his work.<ref>Călinescu, p.690</ref> At a [[French Red Cross]] conference in September, Macedonski paid his final public homage to France, which had just become entangled in [[World War I]].<ref>Boia, p.245</ref> It was also in 1914 that Macedonski commissioned for print his very first [[Rondel (poem)|rondels]] and completed work on a tragedy play about [[Renaissance]] poet [[Dante Aligheri]]—known as ''La Mort de Dante'' in its French original, and ''Moartea lui Dante'' in the secondary Romanian version (both meaning "Dante's Death").<ref>Anghelescu, p.13; Vianu, Vol.II, p.382</ref> The aging poet was by then building connections with the [[Art of Romania|local art scene]]: together with artist [[Alexandru Severin]], he created (and probably presided over) ''Cenaclul idealist'' ("The [[Idealism|Idealist]] Club"), which included Symbolist artists and was placed under the honorary patronage of King Carol.<ref>{{ro icon}} Marian Constantin, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Visuri-si-himere*articleID_21773-articles_details.html "Visuri și himere"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 474, May 2009</ref>
1916 was also the year when Romania abandoned her neutrality and, under a National Liberal government, rallied with the [[Allies of World War I|Entente Powers]]. During the neutrality period, Macedonski had shed his lifelong Francophilia to join the [[Germanophile]]s, who wanted to see Romanian participation on the [[Central Powers]]' side.<ref name="vztcron" /><ref>Boia, p.103, 104, 245-248; Călinescu, p.523; Vianu, Vol.II, p.382-383</ref> In 1915, he issued the journal ''Cuvântul Meu'' ("My Word"). Entirely written by him,<ref name="Anghelescu, p.13">Anghelescu, p.13</ref> it published ten consecutive issues before going bankrupt, and notably lashed out against France for being "[[Bourgeoisie|bourgeois]]" and "lawyer-filled", demanding from Romania not to get involved in the conflict.<ref>Boia, p.245-246; Vianu, Vol.II, p.382</ref> Commentators and researchers of his work have declared themselves puzzled by this change in allegiance.<ref>Boia, p.245-247; Călinescu, p.523; Vianu, Vol.II, p.382</ref>
Macedonski further alienated public opinion during the [[Romanian Campaign (World War I)|Romanian Campaign]], when the Central Powers armies entered southern Romania and [[Battle of Bucharest|occupied Bucharest]]. Alexis was drafted and became a war artist,<ref>Gheorghe Nicolescu, "Imortalizînd eroii de la Mărășești, Mărăști, Oituz", in ''[[Magazin Istoric]]'', August 1977, p.24-25</ref> but Macedonski Sr, who received formal protection from the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bucharest]],<ref>Boia, p.246</ref> chose to stay behind while the authorities and many ordinary citizens relocated to [[Iași]], where resistance was still being organized. His stance was interpreted as [[collaborationism]] by his critics. However, Macedonski reportedly faced extreme poverty throughout the occupation.<ref name="vztcron" /><ref>Boia, p.246; Cernat, p.45; Vianu, Vol.II, p.383</ref> Having by then begun to attend the circle of [[Alexandru Bogdan-Pitești]], his promoter and fellow Germanophile, he was once rewarded by the latter with a turkey filled with gold coins.<ref>Cernat, p.45</ref>
===Late polemics, illness and death=== [[File:Mormant Macedonski.jpg|thumb|Macedonski's grave in [[Bellu Cemetery|Bellu]]]]
''Literatorul'' resumed print in June 1918, once Romania capitulated to the Central Powers under the [[Treaty of Bucharest (1918)|Treaty of Bucharest]].<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.383-384</ref> A controversial incident occurred soon afterwards, when, going against the counsel of his friend and collaborator Stamatiad, Macedonski signed a ''Literatorul'' article where the German military administrator [[August von Mackensen]], who was about to lead his troops out of Romania, was presented in a positive light.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.383-384, 387. See also Boia, p.246-247</ref> In a manner deemed "excessive" by historian [[Lucian Boia]], the Romanian writer was paying homage not just to Mackensen, but also, indirectly, to [[German Emperor]] [[Wilhelm II, German Emperor|Wilhelm II]] and the ''[[German Army (German Empire)|Reichsheer]]''.<ref>Boia, p.246-247</ref> Soon after reading the piece, [[Romanian Academy]] member and fellow Symbolist promoter [[Ovid Densusianu]] withdrew his own nomination of Macedonski for an Academy seat.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.384">Vianu, Vol.II, p.384</ref> During summer, Macedonski also joined the group of public figures who saluted the senior Conservative Germanophile [[Petre P. Carp]] (deeming Carp "the veteran of character, honesty and Romanianism"), and, in September, joined [[Ioan Slavici]] and [[Gala Galaction]] as a contributor to the occupation magazine ''Rumänien in Wort und Bild'', where he prophesied an [[Francophobia|anti-French]] "political renaissance" of Romania.<ref>Boia, p.247</ref>
Alexandru Macedonski faced problems after the Romanian government resumed its control over Bucharest, and during the early years of [[Greater Romania]]. What followed the Mackensen article, Vianu claims, was Macedonski's ''bellum contra omnes'' ("war against all").<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.384"/> However, the poet made efforts to accommodate himself with the triumphal return of the Iași authorities: in December 1918, ''Literatorul'' celebrated the extension of Romanian rule "from the [[Tisza]] to the [[Dniester]]" as a success of the National Liberals, paying homage to Francophile political leaders [[Ion I. C. Brătianu]] and [[Take Ionescu]].<ref>Boia, p.248</ref> Macedonski also envisaged running in the [[Romanian general election, 1918|1918 election]] for a seat in the new [[Parliament of Romania|Parliament]] (which was supposed to vote a document to replace the [[1866 Constitution of Romania|1866 Constitution]] as the organic law), but never registered his candidature.<ref>Călinescu, p.523; Vianu, Vol.II, p.384</ref> According to Vianu, he had intended to create a [[joke political party]], the "intellectual group", whose other member was an unnamed coffeehouse acquaintance of his.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.392</ref> ''Literatorul'' was revived for a final time in 1919.<ref name="Anghelescu, p.13"/>
His health deteriorated from [[heart disease]], which is described by Vianu as an effect of constant smoking.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.393. See also Suciu, p.104</ref> By that stage, Vianu recalls, Macedonski also had problems coming to terms with his age.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.472-473</ref> His last anthumous work was the pamphlet ''Zaherlina'' (named after the Romanian version of "[[Zacherlin]]"; also known as ''Zacherlina'' or ''Zacherlina în continuare'', "Zacherlin Contd."), completed in 1919 and published the following year.<ref>Anghelescu, p.13; Vianu, Vol.II, p.384</ref> It notably attacked Densusianu, who had become Macedonski's personal enemy.<ref name="Anghelescu, p.13"/> Some other polemical texts he had authored late in life saw print only after his death, under the title ''Mustrări postume către o generație neînțelegătoare'' ("Posthumous Reprimands for an Obtuse Generation").<ref name="vztcron" />
1920 was also the year when the [[People's Party (interwar Romania)|People's Party]] cabinet attempted to pension him off from his office at the Historical Monuments Commission, but the publicized protest of Macedonski's fellow writers in Bucharest made it reconsider.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.384"/> Confined to his home by illness and old age, Macedonski was still writing poems, some of which later known as his ''Ultima verba'' ("Last Words").<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.384-385</ref> The writer died on November 24, at three o'clock in the afternoon.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.385</ref> Having come to develop an addiction to floral fragrances, he was inhaling a rose petal extract during his last hours.<ref name="aonarco22" /><ref>Călinescu, p.523. According to Călinescu, the poet's last word was ''rozele'' ("the roses").</ref> He was buried in Bucharest's [[Bellu Cemetery|Bellu]].<ref name="vztcron" />
==Work==
===General characteristics=== [[File:Macedonski Noaptea de maiu.png|thumb|250px|Macedonski's manuscript for ''Noaptea de mai'' (in or around 1887)]]
Although Alexandru Macedonski frequently changed his style and views on literary matters, a number of constants have been traced throughout his work. Thus, a common perception is that his literature had a strongly visual aspect, the notion being condensed in [[Cincinat Pavelescu]]'s definition of Macedonski: "Poet, therefore painter; painter, therefore poet."<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.409">Vianu, Vol.II, p.409</ref> [[Traian Demetrescu]] too recalled that his mentor had been dreaming of becoming a visual artist, and had eventually settled for turning his son Alexis into one.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.409"/> This pictorial approach to writing created parallels between Macedonski and his traditionalist contemporaries [[Vasile Alecsandri]] and [[Barbu Ștefănescu Delavrancea]].<ref>Călinescu, p.318, 569; Vianu, Vol.III, p.40, 451</ref>
Following the tenets of [[Dimitrie Bolintineanu]] and [[Théophile Gautier]], the writer repeatedly called for purity in [[Meter (poetry)|versification]], and upheld it as an essential requirement,<ref>Călinescu, p.242, 516, 523-524, 683</ref> while progressively seeking to verify the quality of his poetry through [[phonaesthetics]].<ref>Anghelescu, p.28-29</ref> A characteristic of Macedonski's style is his inventive use of [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. Initially influenced by [[Ion Heliade Rădulescu]]'s introduction of Italian-based words to the [[Romanian lexis]], Macedonski himself later infused poetic language with a large array of neologisms from several [[Romance languages|Romance]] sources.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.415-416, 459-460</ref> Likewise, Vianu notes, Macedonski had a tendency for comparing nature with the artificial, the result of this being a "document" of his values.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.450-451</ref> Macedonski's language alternated neologisms with [[Barbarism (modern linguistics)|barbarisms]], many of which were coined by him personally.<ref>Călinescu, p.525; Sandqvist, p.200; Vianu, Vol.II, p.451</ref> They include ''claviculat'' ("[[clavicle]]d", applied to a shoulder), ''împălăriată'' ("enhatted", used to define a crowd of hat-wearing tourists),<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.451</ref> and ''ureichii'' (instead of ''urechii'', "to the ear" or "of the ear").<ref name="Călinescu, p.525">Călinescu, p.525</ref> His narratives nevertheless take an interest in recording direct speech, used as a method of characterization.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.449-450, 456</ref> However, Călinescu criticizes Macedonski for using a language which, "although grammatically correct [...], seems to have been learned only recently", as well as for not following other Romanian writers in creating a lasting poetic style.<ref name="Călinescu, p.525"/>
The writer's belief in the effects of sheer willpower, notably present in his comments on [[Esotericism|esoteric]] subjects, was itself a defining characteristic of his perspective on literature. In 1882, he wrote about progression in one's career: "We are all poets at birth, but only those who shape themselves through study will become poets."<ref>Călinescu, p.524; Vianu, Vol.II, p.386</ref> Vianu, who notes Macedonski's "exclusivity" and "fanaticism", places such statements in connection with Macedonski's personal ambition, "pride" and "the willingness to carry out ventured actions [...], in stated opposition with the entire surrounding and with contempt for the foreseeable reaction."<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.387-388</ref>
Almost all periods of Macedonski's work reflect, in whole or in part, his public persona and the polemics he was involved in. George Călinescu's emits a verdict on the relation between his lifetime notoriety and the public's actual awareness of his work: "Macedonski [was] a poet well-known for being an unknown poet."<ref name="Călinescu, p.521"/> According to literary critic [[Matei Călinescu]], the innovative aspects of his impact on [[Literature of Romania|Romanian literature]] were not as much related to his "literary ideology", as much as to his "contradictory spirit" and "essential nonconformism".<ref name="Cernat, p.11"/> However, literary researcher [[Adrian Marino]] proposes that Macedonski was one of the first modern authors to illustrate the importance of "[[dialectic]] unity" through his views on art, in particular by having argued that poetry needed to be driven by "an idea".<ref>Anghelescu, p.28</ref> Having theorized once, while questioning ''Junimist'' rigor, that "the logic of poetry is ''absurdity'' itself [italics in the original]",<ref>Călinescu, p.516. Paraphrased by Sandqvist, p.197, 199.</ref> the poet also said: "Poetry is the chaos of spirit and matter, of the cries of distress and mad laughter. From the sublime to the trivial, that is what it should be."<ref>Răileanu & Carassou, p.152. Paraphrased by Sandqvist, p.25, 199.</ref> He later revised part of this verdict, and, making explicit his adoption of [[aestheticism]], spoke against trivial subjects and in favor of the sublime.<ref name="Sandqvist, p.200">Sandqvist, p.200</ref>
While Macedonski also discarded the concept of "social poetry" not long after postulating it, its spirit, Tudor Vianu believes, can still be found in his later contributions. This, the critic notes, was owed to his "social temperament", whose "fundamental experience is that of the social."<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.402</ref> Discussing this sociable and extrovert character, other critics see in the poet's life and work the imprint of "[[quixotism]]".<ref>Anghelescu, p.140; Cernat, p.8, 16; Sandqvist, p.200</ref><ref name="arteodo">Alexandru Ruja, chronological table, in [[Păstorel Teodoreanu]], ''Tămâie și otravă'', [[Editura de Vest]], Timișoara, 1994, p.14-15. {{ISBN|973-36-0165-9}}</ref> Also according to Vianu, this contrasted with Macedonski's failures in communicating with the public, an experience which made him "[[Misanthropy|misanthropic]]" and contributed to his ultimate vision of death as freedom.<ref>Anghelescu, p.137; Vianu, Vol.II, p.403-406, 434-435</ref> Literary historian [[Pompiliu Constantinescu]] concluded: "Macedonski could not resign; his one martyrdom was for Art, as the sole liberation from a tormented life."<ref>Anghelescu, p.138</ref> Other commentators have defined the poet's perspective on life as a result of "[[neurosis]]".<ref name="Sandqvist, p.200"/>
In Vianu's perspective, Macedonski's stance is dominated by a mixture of [[nostalgia]], [[sensuality]], lugubrious-grotesque imagery, and "the lack of bashfulness for antisocial sentiments" which compliments his [[sarcasm]].<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.404-405</ref> In respect to the latter characteristic, Vianu notes "no one in Romanian literature has laughed the same way as Macedonski",<ref>Anghelescu, p.137; Vianu, Vol.II, p.405</ref> whereas critic [[Ștefan Cazimir]] argues: "[Macedonski was] lacking the sense of relativity in principles, and implicitly a sense of humor." Cazimir adds: "Only when he aged did [Macedonski] learn to smile".<ref name="stcantxvii">[[Ștefan Cazimir]], preface to ''Antologia umorului liric'', [[Editura Minerva]], Bucharest, 1977, p.XVII. {{OCLC|251657588}}</ref> George Călinescu himself believes Macedonski to have been "fundamentally a spiritual man with lots of humor", speculating that he was able to see the "uselessness" of his own scientific ventures.<ref name="Călinescu, p.523"/>
Critics note that, while Macedonski progressed from one stage to the other, his work fluctuated between artistic accomplishment and mediocrity.<ref>Călinescu, p.523-524, 525-526, 527, 528; Vianu, Vol.II, p.393, 394, 480-481</ref> Tudor Vianu believes "failure in reaching originality" and reliance on "soppy-conventional attributes of the day" to be especially evident wherever Macedonski tried to emulate [[epic poetry]].<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.394</ref> He also notes that Macedonski's love-themed pieces "cannot be listed among [his] most fortunate".<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.398">Vianu, Vol.II, p.398</ref> At his best, commentators note, he was one of the Romanian literature's classics.<ref name="mzrivalul"/><ref>Călinescu, p.523; Vianu, Vol.II, p.393-394</ref> Macedonski is thus perceived as the author second only to Eminescu, and as his ideal counterpart—a relation Vianu describes as "the internal [[Dualistic cosmology|dualism]] [confronting] two [[Lares|familiar gods]]".<ref>Vianu, Vol.III, p.353-354</ref> Various critics have compared Eminescu's poetic discourse with that of the Symbolist leader, concluding that the two poets often display very similar attitudes.<ref name="mzrivalul"/><ref>Anghelescu, p.24, 27-28; Călinescu, p.518, 524, 526</ref> Călinescu writes that, while Macedonski's work is largely inferior to that of his ''Junimist'' rival, it forms the best "reply" ever conceived within their common setting.<ref name="Călinescu, p.527">Călinescu, p.527</ref>
===''Prima verba'' and other early works=== With [[Ion Catina]], [[Vasile Păun]] and [[Grigore H.
