Grandea]], young Macedonski belonged to late Romanian [[Romanticism]], part of a [[Neo-romanticism|Neoromantic]] generation which had for its mentors Heliade Rădulescu and Bolintineanu.<ref name="mzrivalul"/><ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.388, 479-480</ref> Other early influences were [[Pierre-Jean de Béranger]] and [[Gottfried August Bürger]], together with [[Romanian folklore]], motifs from them being adapted by Macedonski into [[pastoral]]s and [[Ballade (forme fixe)|ballade]]s of ca. 1870-1880.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.394-395, 397</ref> The imprint of Romanticism and such other sources was evident in ''[[Prima verba]]'', which groups pieces that Macedonski authored in his early youth, the earliest of them being written when he was just twelve.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.344">Vianu, Vol.II, p.344</ref> Critics generally argue that the volume is without value.<ref>Călinescu, p.523; Vianu, Vol.II, p.344</ref> The poems display his rebellious attitude, [[self-victimization]] and strong reliance on autobiographical elements, centering on such episodes as the death of his father.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.344"/> In one piece inspired by the ideology of Heliade Rădulescu, Vianu notes, Macedonski sings "the [[French Revolution]]'s love for freedom and equality, otherwise proclaimed from his nobleman's perspective."<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.343">Vianu, Vol.II, p.343</ref> It reads: {{Verse translation| {{lang|ro|Când acum poporul vedem că studiază Să nu avem ură când se luminează, Ca frați să-l iubim!}}<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.343"/> | Now that we see the people studying Let us not be hating them while they grow enlightened, Let us love them like brothers!}}
In parallel, Macedonski used [[Erotic literature|erotic themes]], completing a series which, although written on the model of idylls, is noted for its brute details of sexual exploits. The poet probably acknowledged that posterity would reject them, and did not republish them in any of his collected poetry volumes.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.398"/>
During his time at ''Oltul'' (1873–1875), Macedonski published a series of poems, most of which were not featured in definitive editions of his work.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.345-346</ref> In addition to [[ode]]s written in the Italian-based version of [[Romanian language|Romanian]], it includes lyrics which satirize [[Carol I of Romania|Carol I]] without mentioning his name.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.346"/> Following his arrest, Macedonski also completed ''Celula mea de la Văcărești'' ("My Cell in Văcărești"), which shows his attempt to joke about the situation.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.347"/> In contrast to this series, some of the pieces written during Macedonski's time in the [[Budjak]] and [[Northern Dobruja]] display a detachment from contemporary themes. At that stage, he was especially inspired by [[George Gordon Byron, 6th Baron Byron|Lord Byron]], whom Vianu calls "the sovereign poet of [Macedonski's] youth."<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.349"/> In ''Calul arabului'', Macedonski explores [[Exoticism|exotic]] and [[Levant]]ine settings, using symbols which announce [[George Coșbuc]]'s ''[[El-Zorab]]'',<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.348" /><ref name="elrseisl" /> and the [[Venice|Venetian]]-themed ''Ithalo'', which centers on episodes of betrayal and murder.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.349"/> Others were epic and [[patriotism|patriotic]] in tone, with subjects such as Romanian victories in the [[Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)|Russo-Turkish War]] or the [[Roman Empire|Imperial Roman]] sites along the [[Danube]].<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.348, 349, 395-398</ref> One of these pieces, titled ''Hinov'' after the village and stone quarry in [[Rasova]], gives Macedonski a claim to being the first modern European poet to have used [[free verse]], ahead of the French Symbolist [[Gustave Kahn]].<ref>Călinescu, p.525; Vianu, Vol.II, p.349</ref> Macedonski himself later voiced the claim, and referred to such a technique as "symphonic verse", "proteic verse", or, in honor of composer [[Richard Wagner]], "Wagnerian verse".<ref>Călinescu, p.525; Răileanu & Carassou, p.7, 152; Sandqvist, p.199</ref>
While editing ''Oltul'', Macedonski also completed his first prose writings. These were the [[Travel writing|travel account]] ''Pompeia și Sorento'' ("Pompeia and Sorento", 1874) and a prison-themed story described by Vianu as "a tearjerker", titled ''Câinele din Văcărești'' ("The Dog in Văcărești", 1875).<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.419</ref> These were later complemented by other travel works, which critic [[Mihai Zamfir]] likens to the verbal experiments of [[Impressionist literature]], pioneering in the Romanian [[prose poetry]] genre.<ref name="mzrivalul"/> The short comedy ''Gemenii'' was his debut work for the stage, but, according to Vianu, failed to show any merit other than a "logical construction" and a preview into Macedonski's use of sarcasm.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.452"/> These writings were followed in 1876 by a concise biography of [[Cârjaliul]], an early 19th-century [[hajduk]].<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.419-420</ref> In line with his first Levant-themed poems, Macedonski authored the 1877 story ''Așa se fac banii'' ("This Is How Money Is Made", later retold in French as ''Comment on devient riche et puissant'', "How to Become Rich and Powerful"), a [[fable]] of [[fatalism]] and the [[Muslim world]]—it dealt with two brothers, one hard-working and one indolent, the latter of whom earns his money through a series of serendipitous events.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.420, 434</ref> Likewise, his [[Verse drama and dramatic verse|verse comedy]] ''Iadeș!'' borrowed its theme from the widely circulated collection of [[Persian literature]] known as ''Sindipa''.<ref name="elrseisl" /><ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.452-453">Vianu, Vol.II, p.452-453</ref> The setting was however modern, and, as noted by French-born critic [[Frédéric Damé]], the plot also borrowed much from [[Émile Augier]]'s ''Gabrielle'' and from other [[morality play]]s of the period.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.452-453" /> Part of the text was an ironic treatment of youth in [[liberal profession]]s, an attitude which Macedonski fitted in his emerging anti-[[bourgeois]] discourse.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.454-455</ref>
With the first poems in his ''[[Nights (Macedonski)|Nights]]'' cycle, Macedonski still showed his allegiance to Romanticism, and in particular to [[Alphonse de Lamartine]],<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.398"/> and the supposed inventor of this theme, [[Alfred de Musset]].<ref name="mzrivalul"/><ref>Anghelescu, p.16-18, 24-25; Călinescu, p.524; Suciu, p.105-106</ref> ''Noaptea de noiembrie'' opens with a violent condemnation of his adversaries, and sees Macedonski depicting his own funeral.<ref>Anghelescu, p.22-23</ref> The poem is commended by Călinescu, who notes that, in contrast to the "apparently trivial beginning", the main part, where Macedonski depicts himself in flight over the [[Danube]], brings the Romanian writer close to the accomplishments of [[Dante Aligheri]].<ref name="Călinescu, p.528">Călinescu, p.528</ref> The writer himself claimed that the piece evidenced "the uttermost breath of inspiration I have ever felt in my life."<ref>Anghelescu, p.14</ref> Another poem, ''Noaptea de aprilie'' ("April Night"), was probably his testimony of [[unrequited love]] for [[Aristizza Romanescu]].<ref>Nastasă, p.94</ref>
===Realism and Naturalism=== By the 1880s, Macedonski developed and applied his "social poetry" theory, as branch of [[Literary realism|Realism]]. Explained by the writer himself as a reaction against the legacy of Lamartine,<ref>Călinescu, p.523; Vianu, Vol.II, p.398-399</ref> it also signified his brief affiliation with the [[Naturalism (literature)|Naturalist]] current, a radical segment of the Realist movement. [[Traian Demetrescu]] thus noted that Macedonski cherished the works of French Naturalists and Realists such as [[Gustave Flaubert]] and [[Émile Zola]].<ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.389, 421. See also Suciu, p.106</ref> During this phase, Macedonski made known his sympathy for the disinherited, from girls forced into prostitution to convicts sentenced to [[penal labor]] on salt mines, and also spoke out against the conventionalism of [[civil marriage]]s.<ref>Călinescu, p.524; Vianu, Vol.II, p.398-402</ref> His ''Ocnele'' ("The Salt Mines") includes the verdict: {{Verse translation| {{lang|ro|Vai! Ce-am convenit cu toții a numi soțietate Mult mai demnă ca tâlharii e de-acest cumplit locaș! Statul e o ficțiune, iar dreptatea—strâmbătate, Care duce omenirea dintr-un hop într-un făgaș.}}<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.400</ref> | Alas! What we have all agreed to deem society Is far more suited than bandits are for this terrible dwelling! State is fiction, and justice—an injustice That leads humanity from a bump down into a rut.}}
Naturalist depiction was also the main element in his prose pieces of the early 1880s. Among them was the first of several [[Sketch story|sketch stories]] using [[still life]] techniques, ''Casa cu nr. 10''<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.420-421, 425-426</ref> (according to Zamfir, a prime sample of Macedonski's "ornamental" genre).<ref name="mzrivalul"/> With ''Între cotețe'', ''Dramă banală'' and later ''Cometa lui Odorescu'' ("Odorescu's Comet"), Macedonski speaks about his own biography.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.426-427</ref> The former has for a protagonist Pandele Vergea, a thirty-five-year-old man who is consumed by an [[Aviculture|avicultural]] obsession, who dreams of turning into a bird, and who is eventually maimed by his overcrowded fowls.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.427-429</ref> In contrast, Dereanu is a [[Bohemianism|bohemian]] university student, possessed by dreams of military and political glory, and who meditates about his future in front of Heliade Rădulescu's statue or in Bucharest cafés.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.429-430</ref> Also a bohemian, Odorescu announces his discovery of a comet, before being proved wrong by his aunt, an ordinary woman.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.430</ref> Some pieces also double as [[memoir]]s: in ''Dramă banală'', the plot revolves around Macedonski's recollection of the 1866 plebiscite.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.423" /> Vianu draws attention to the [[picturesque]] depiction of [[History of Bucharest|historic Bucharest]], a contributing element in ''Cometa...'', ''Casa cu nr. 10'' and ''Între cotețe''.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.425-426, 430, 432-433</ref>
With ''Unchiașul Sărăcie'' (also written in verse), Macedonski took Naturalist tenets into the field of drama. Frédéric Damé believed it an imitation of a play by [[Ernest d'Hervilly]] and [[Alfred Grévin]], but, Vianu argues, the Romanian text was only loosely based on theirs: in Macedonski's adaptation, the theme became [[fairy tale]]-like, and used a speech style based on [[Romanian folklore]].<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.455-456</ref> Around the time of its completion, Macedonski was also working on a similarly loose adaptation of [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'', which notably had the two protagonists die in each other's arms.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.457-458</ref> Another such play is ''3 decemvrie'' ("December 3"), which partly retells [[Friedrich Ludwig Zacharias Werner]]'s ''Der 24 Februar'' using Naturalist devices.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.459-462</ref> By contrast, the homage-play ''Cuza-Vodă'' is mainly a Romantic piece, where [[Alexander John Cuza]] finds his political mission validated by legendary figures in [[History of Romania|Romanian history]].<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.462"/>
In parallel, Macedonski was using poetry to carry out his polemics. In an 1884 [[epigram]], he reacted against Alecsandri's ''[[Fântâna Blanduziei]]'', but, in Vianu's definition, "his regular causticity seems to be restrained."<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.353"/> The piece he had earlier written, presumably against Eminescu, scandalized the public by mocking the rival's mental ruin: {{Verse translation| {{lang|ro|Un X... pretins poet—acum S-a dus pe cel mai jalnic drum... L-aș plânge dacă-n balamuc Destinul său n-ar fi mai bun Căci până ieri a fost năuc Și nu e azi decât nebun.}}<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.354. Partly rendered in Perpessicus, p.352</ref> | An X... who calls himself a poet—has now Gone down that most pathetic road... I'd cry for him if in bedlam His fate were not one for the best As up to yesterday he had been dopey And now he is merely insane.}}
According to Tudor Vianu, Macedonski was mostly motivated by his disappointment in ''Junimea'', and in particular by Eminescu's response to his public persona. Vianu contends that, although Macedonski "never was familiar with the resigned and patient attitudes", he was "by no means an evil man."<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.358</ref> On one occasion, the poet defended himself against criticism, noting that the epigram had not been specifically addressed to Eminescu, but had been labeled as such by the press, and claiming to have authored it years before its ''Literatorul'' edition.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.359-360. According to Vianu, Macedonski also stated that poet [[Dumitru Constantinescu-Teleormăneanu]] had published the piece without his knowledge, because he liked it and had learned it by heart. Novelist [[I. Peltz]] later claimed that Teleormăneanu was the poem's real author: {{ro icon}} [[Al. Săndulescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/index.pl/i._peltz_memorialist "I. Peltz memorialist"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 35/2004.</ref> However, the later piece ''Viața de apoi'' ("The Afterlife") still displays resentments he harbored toward Eminescu.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.357</ref>
By 1880-1884, particularly after the Eminescu scandal, Macedonski envisaged prioritizing French as his language of expression.<ref>Anghelescu, p.11; Vianu, Vol.II, p.361, 362</ref> According to Vianu, Macedonski had traversed "the lowest point" of his existence, and had been subject to "one of the most delicate mysteries of poetic creation."<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.363" /> Among his pieces of the period is the French-language [[sonnet]] ''Pârle, il me dit alors'' ("Speak, He Then Said to Me"), where, Vianu notes, "one discovers the state of mind of a poet who decides to expatriate himself."<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.361"/>
===Adoption of Symbolism=== [[File:Fleurs-du-mal ame du vin schlussvignette.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Carlos Schwabe]]'s ''Âme du vin'' ("Soul of the Wine"), illustration for [[Charles Baudelaire]]'s ''[[Les Fleurs du mal]]'']]
According to Mihai Zamfir, at the end of his transition from the "mimetic and egocentric" verse to Symbolist poetry, Macedonski emerged a "remarkable, often extraordinary" author.<ref name="mzrivalul"/> In the early 20th century, fellow poet and critic [[N. Davidescu]] described Macedonski, [[Ion Minulescu]] and other Symbolists from [[Wallachia]] as distinct from their [[Moldavia]]n counterparts in both style and themes.<ref>Cernat, p.17. Cernat notes that the same view is held by Vianu.</ref> Endorsing the theory and practice of Symbolism for much of his life, Macedonski retrospectively claimed to have been one of its first exponents.<ref>Călinescu, p.525; Cernat, p.12</ref> His version of Symbolism, critic [[Paul Cernat]] notes, clashed with that advocated by many of his contemporaries in that it rejected merit to the [[Decadent movement]], and represented the "decorative" [[Aestheticism|aestheticist]] trend of [[Parnassianism|Paranassian]] spirit within the [[Symbolist movement in Romania|Romanian Symbolist current]].<ref>Cernat, p.11-12, 16</ref>
Within ''Poezia viitorului'', Macedonski invoked as his models to follow some important or secondary Symbolist and Parnassian figures: [[Charles Baudelaire]], [[Joséphin Péladan]], [[Maurice Maeterlinck]], [[Stéphane Mallarmé]] and [[Jean Moréas]].<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.366</ref> In his review of ''Bronzes'' for ''[[Mercure de France]]'', [[Pierre Quillard]] remarked the "irreproachable" technique, but criticized the poet for being too indebted to both Baudelaire and [[Charles Marie René Leconte de Lisle|Leconte de Lisle]];<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.371"/> other Symbolist figures whom Macedonski is known to have borrowed from are [[José María de Heredia]]<ref name="Călinescu, p.526">Călinescu, p.526</ref> and [[Iwan Gilkin]].<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.413</ref> While undergoing this transition, to what linguist Manuela-Delia Suciu argues is a mostly Parnassian phase,<ref>Suciu, p.107-109</ref> Macedonski was still referencing Naturalism, and considered it compatible with Symbolism.<ref>Krasztev, "From Modernization...", p.345</ref>
With the adoption of such tenets came a succession of Symbolist poems, where the focus is on minutely-observed objects, usually items of luxury, partly reflecting themes he had explored in the Naturalist stage. Commenting on them, Tudor Vianu argues that no such works had ever been produced in Romanian literature up until that moment.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.410">Vianu, Vol.II, p.410</ref> In his ''Ospățul lui Pentaur'' ("The Feast of [[Pentaur]]"), the poet reflected on civilization itself, as reflected in inanimate opulence.<ref name="mzrivalul"/><ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.410"/> The motif was also developed in descriptive prose fragments later grouped in ''Cartea de aur'', collectively titled ''nuvele fără oameni'' ("novellas without people") and compared by Călinescu with the paintings of [[Theodor Aman]].<ref>Călinescu, p.318, 528</ref>
Also during that stage, Macedonski was exploring the numerous links between Symbolism, [[mysticism]] and [[esotericism]]. Earlier pieces had already come to explore [[macabre]] themes characteristic for an early branch of Symbolism. Influenced by [[Maurice Rollinat]], they include the somber ''Vaporul morții'' ("The Ship of Death") and ''Visul fatal'' ("The Fatal Dream").<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.363-364, 412</ref> Likewise, the piece titled ''Imnul lui Satan'' ("Satan's Hymn") was placed by critics in connection with ''[[Les Litanies de Satan]]'' (part of Baudelaire's ''[[Les Fleurs du mal]]''), but, Vianu argues, the source of Macedonski's satanic themes may have been lodged in his own vision of the world.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.407-408</ref> This interest also reflected in his 1893 ''Saul'', where [[Cincinat Pavelescu]]'s contribution is supposedly minimal.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.463</ref> Echoing satanic themes, [[Ernest Legouvé]]'s dramatic version of the ''[[Medea]]'' myth (which Macedonski translated at some point in his life)<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.463-464</ref> and the classical work of [[Jean Racine]],<ref name="mzrivalul"/> it shows the dark powers of political conflict intervening between the eponymous king and his ''[[ephebos]]''-like protégé [[David]], the latter of whom turns out to be the agent of spiritual revolution.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.464-467</ref>
''{{lang|ro|Noaptea de august}}'' ("August Night"), outlines a [[Monism|monistic]] belief probably inspired by [[Rosicrucianism]], stressing the unity between soul and matter and depicting Macedonski's own journey into a transcendental space.<ref>Krasztev, "From a Deadlocked Present...", p.43</ref> Following the examples of Baudelaire's ''[[Les paradis artificiels]]'', but also echoing his readings from [[Paul Verlaine]] and [[Théophile Gautier]], Macedonski left poems dealing with [[narcotic]]s and [[substance abuse]], at least some of which reflected his personal experience with [[nicotine]] and possibly other unnamed drugs.<ref name="aonarco22" /> Also at that stage, Macedonski also began publishing the "instrumentalist" series of his Symbolist poems. This form of [[Experimental literature|experimental poem]] was influenced by the theories of [[René Ghil]]<ref>Călinescu, p.525; Vianu, Vol.II, p.366, 413-415</ref> and verified through his encounter with [[Remy de Gourmont]]'s views.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.413-415</ref> In parallel, it reaffirmed Macedonski's personal view that music and the spoken word were intimately related (a perspective notably attested by his 1906 interview with [[Jules Combarieu]]).<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.341-342"/> Romanian critic [[Petre Răileanu]] theorized that such elements evidenced Macedonski's transition to "[[metaliterature]]".<ref name="Sandqvist, p.200"/> On a different level, they echoed an older influence, that of [[Gottfried August Bürger]].<ref name="Călinescu, p.526" />
===''Excelsior''=== Despite having stated his interest in innovation, Macedonski generally displayed a more conventional style in his ''[[Excelsior (Macedonski)|Excelsior]]'' volume. It included ''Noaptea de mai'', which Vianu sees as "one of the [vernacular's] most beautiful poems"<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.363" /> and as evidence of "a clear joy, without any torment whatsoever".<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.408</ref> A celebration of spring partly evoking folkloric themes, it was made famous by the recurring [[refrain]], ''Veniți: privighetoarea cântă și liliacul e-nflorit'' ("Come along: the nightingale is singing and the lilac is in blossom").<ref>Anghelescu, p.20-21</ref> Like ''Noaptea de mai'', ''Lewki'' (named after and dedicated to the [[Snake Island (Black Sea)|Snake Island]]), depicts intense joy, completed in this case by what Vianu calls "the restorative touch of nature."<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.409"/> The series also returned to [[Levant]] settings and [[Islam]]ic imagery, particularly in ''Acșam dovalar'' (named after the [[Turkish language|Turkish]] version of ''[[Witr]]'').<ref name="elrseisl" /> Also noted within the volume is his short "Modern [[Psalms]]" series, including the piece ''Iertare'' ("Forgiveness"), which is addressed to God: {{Verse translation| {{lang|ro|Iertare! Sunt ca orice om M-am îndoit de-a ta putere, Am râs de sfintele mistere Ce sunt în fiecare-atom... Iertare! Sunt ca orice om.}}<ref name="Călinescu, p.526">Călinescu, p.526</ref> | Forgiveness! I'm like any man I have been doubting your power I derided the sacred mysteries That lie within each of the atoms... Forgiveness! I'm like any man.}}
''Excelsior'' also included ''Noaptea de ianuarie'' ("January Night"), which encapsulates one of his best-known political statements.<ref>Anghelescu, p.21-22; Ornea, p.263; Vianu, Vol.II, p.368</ref> Anghelescu reads it as a "meditation on disillusionment that culminates in a vitality-laden exhortation of action."<ref>Anghelescu, p.19</ref> Its anti-[[bourgeois]] attitude, literary historian [[Z. Ornea]] argues, was one of the meeting points between Macedonski and ''Junimism''.<ref>Ornea, p.263</ref> In what is seen as its most acid section, the text notably reads: {{Verse translation| {{lang|ro|M-am născut în niște zile când tâmpita burghezime Din tejghea făcând tribună, legiune de coțcari, Pune-o talpă noroioasă pe popor și boierime, Zile când se-mparte țara în călăi și în victime Și când steagul libertății e purtat de cârciumari.}}<ref>Anghelescu, p.21; Vianu, Vol.II, p.368</ref> | I was born into days when the moronic bourgeoisie Turning counters into rostrums, a legion of knaves, Places a muddy sole on the people and the boyars, Days when the country is divided into hangmen and victims And when the flag of liberty is carried by publicans.}}
At the same time as being engaged in his most violent polemics, Macedonski produced meditative and serene poems, which were later judged to be among his best. ''Noaptea de decemvrie'' is the synthesis of his main themes and influences, rated by commentators as his "masterpiece".<ref name="elrseisl" /><ref>Călinescu, p.527; Vianu, Vol.II, p.410</ref> Partly based on an earlier poem (''Meka'', named after the [[Mecca|Arab city]]),<ref name="elrseisl" /><ref>Anghelescu, p.25</ref> it tells the story of an [[emir]], who, left unsatisfied by the shallow and opulent life he leads in [[Baghdad]], decides to leave on [[Hajj|pilgrimage]]. While critics agree that it is to be read as an [[allegory]] of Macedonski's biography, the ironic text does not make it clear whether the emir actually reaches his target, nor if the central [[metaphor]] of Mecca as a [[mirage]] means that the goal is not worth sacrificing for.<ref name="elrseisl" /><ref>Anghelescu, p.25-26, 30-31; Perpessicius, p.63; Sandqvist, p.201</ref> While [[Mircea Anghelescu]] comments that Macedonski illustrates "unusual tension" by rigorously amplifying references to the color red, seen as a symbol of suffering,<ref>Anghelescu, p.26</ref> Călinescu notes that the sequence of lyrics has a studied "delirious" element, and illustrates this with the quote: {{Verse translation| {{lang|ro|Și el e emirul, și toate le are... E tânăr, e farmec, e trăsnet, e zeu, Dar zilnic se simte furat de-o visare... Spre Meka se duce cu gândul mereu, Și-n fața dorinței—ce este—dispare Iar el e emirul, și toate le are.}}<ref name="Călinescu, p.527"/> | And he is the emir, and he owns each thing... He's young, he's a charm, he's a bolt, he's a god, But in each day he feels he is swept by a dream... Towards Mecca his though races constantly, And faced with the wish, all things disappear, And he is the emir, and he owns each thing.}}
===Late prose works=== In prose, his focus shifted back to the purely descriptive, or led Alexandru Macedonski into the realm of [[fantasy literature]]. These stories, most of which were eventually collected in ''Cartea de aur'', include memoirs of his childhood in the [[Amaradia River (Dolj)|Amaradia]] region, nostalgic portrayals of the [[Oltenia]]n [[Boyars of Wallachia and Moldavia|boyar]] environment, idealized depictions of Cuza's reign, as well as a retrospective view on the [[Slavery in Romania|end of Rom slavery]] (found in his piece ''Verigă țiganul'', "Verigă the Gypsy").<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.422-424, 431-432</ref> The best-known among them is ''Pe drum de poștă'', a [[third-person narrative]] and thinly disguised memoir, where the characters are an adolescent Alexandru Macedonski and his father, [[Alexandru D. Macedonski|General Macedonski]].<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.334, 424-425, 427</ref> The idyllic outlook present in such stories is one of the common meeting points between his version of Symbolism and traditionalist authors such as [[Barbu Ștefănescu Delavrancea]].<ref>Cernat, p.19; Vianu, Vol.II, p.431, 432</ref> Vianu indicates the connection, but adds: "Macedonski descended, through memory, in the world of the village, with the tremor of regret for the peace and plenty of the old settlements, so well polished that each person, landowner as well as peasant, lived within a framework that nature itself seemed to have granted. [...] in depicting rural environments, Macedonski presents the point of view of a [[Conservatism|conservative]]."<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.432</ref>
''[[Thalassa, Le Calvaire de feu]]'', a fantasy novel and extended [[Prose poetry|prose poem]], was celebrated by Macedonski's disciple [[Oreste Georgescu]] as "the new religion of humanity".<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.377</ref> The volume carried the mocking dedication "To France, this [[Chaldea]]" (thought by Vianu to reference Péladan's views on the decay of civilization).<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.436"/> It has affinities with writings by the Italian [[Decadent movement|Decadent]] author [[Gabriele d'Annunzio]],<ref>Călinescu, p.528; Cernat, p.89; Vianu, Vol.II, p.436-437, 444</ref> as well as echoes from [[Anatole France]].<ref name="mds106">Suciu, p.106</ref> The hero Thalassa, a Greek boy, works as a [[lighthouse]]-keeper on Snake Island, fantasizing about the [[golden age]] of mankind.<ref name="cmmareroman"/><ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.440-441</ref> His fate is changed by a shipwreck, during which a girl, Caliope, reaches the island's shore. Thalassa and Caliope fall in love, but are mysteriously unable to seal their union through sexual intercourse: the boy attributes this failure to the "curse" of human individuality. Seeking to achieve a perfect union with his lover, he eventually kills her and drowns himself in the [[Black Sea]].<ref name="cmmareroman"/><ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.441-442; Suciu, p.106-107</ref>
In her review for ''[[Mercure de France]]'', novelist [[Rachilde]] argued: "Very difficult to read, entirely developed in Symbolist manner [and] almost impossible to recount, obviously written in French but nevertheless obviously conceived by a Romanian (and what a spirited Romanian!)."<ref name="Vianu, Vol. II, p.438-439"/> Rachilde believed the work to display "the fragrance of Oriental spices [...] rose marmalade and a slice of bear meat."<ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.439</ref> According to Vianu, the book builds on Macedonski's earlier themes, replacing Naturalist observation with a [[Metaphysics|metaphysical]] speculation about [[idealism]].<ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.442-444</ref> One other aspect of Macedonski's stylistic exploration took him to attempt recording [[synesthesia]]. His manuscript is written in ink of several colors, which, he believed, was to help readers get a full sense of its meaning.<ref>Călinescu, p.525; Vianu, Vol. II, p.445</ref> Like other synesthetic aspects of his novel, this is believed to have been inspired by the techniques of Baudelaire<ref>Răileanu & Carassou, p.152; Sandqvist, p.199; Vianu, Vol. II, p.445</ref> and [[Arthur Rimbaud]].<ref>Răileanu & Carassou, p.152; Sandqvist, p.199</ref>
''Thalassa, Le Calvaire de feu'' is noted for its numerous cultural references, and especially for using a wide range of metaphors. Such aspects have been reviewed negatively by modern critics. Tudor Vianu writes: "the poet makes such waste of gemstones that we feel like saying some of them must be false",<ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.444</ref> while Călinescu, who notes that some fragments reveal "an incomparable artist" and "a professional metaphorist", notes that "in the end, such virtuosities become a bore."<ref name="Călinescu, p.528" /> According to Manuela-Delia Suciu, ''Thalassa'' is "prolix" and "too polished",<ref name="mds106"/> traits believed by Zamfir to be less irritating in the Romanian version.<ref name="mzrivalul"/> Critic Cornel Moraru found that, in the background, ''Thalassa'', a "great Symbolist novel", confronts [[Greek mythology|Ancient Greek]] and [[Christian mythology]], but "abuses" the religious vocabulary.<ref name="cmmareroman"/> Another part of the novel's imagery is [[Erotic literature|erotic]], and includes an elaborate and aestheticized description of male genitalia.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.jurnalul.ro/index.php?section=rubrici&article_id=35631 "Sex în scris, sex de scris!"], in ''[[Jurnalul Național]]'', October 9, 2005</ref>
The four-act [[tragicomedy]] ''Le Fou?'' is seen by Vianu as comparable in subject matter and depth to ''[[Enrico IV]]'', a celebrated 1922 play by [[Luigi Pirandello]].<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.378, 470-471</ref> The plot reflects Macedonski's confrontation with his critics, and his acceptance of the fact that people saw in him an eccentric.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.378, 467-468, 470, 472</ref> The central figure is a banker, Dorval, who identifies himself with [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon Bonaparte]] to the point where he sees episodes in his biography as mirrors of early 19th-century battles. Unlike patients with [[dissociative identity disorder]], Dorval does not actually imagine his life has become Napoleon's, but rather joins with him on an intellectual level.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.469-470</ref> Witnesses of this disorder are divided into family, who seek to have Dorval committed, and close friends, who come to see his take on life as a manifestation of genius.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.471</ref> The spectator is led to believe that the latter interpretation is the correct one.<ref name="Călinescu, p.529" /> At a larger level, Vianu indicates, the play is also Macedonski's critique of [[capitalism]], and, using Parisian [[argot]], makes allusive references to famous people of the day.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.471-472</ref>
Particularly during the 1890s, Macedonski was a follower of [[Edgar Allan Poe]] and of [[Gothic fiction]] in general, producing a Romanian version of Poe's ''[[Metzengerstein]]'' story, urging his own disciples to translate other such pieces, and adopting "Gothic" themes in his original prose.<ref>Thomas C. Carlson, "Poe in Romania", in Lois Vines (ed.), ''Poe Abroad. Influence, Reputation, Affinities'', [[University of Iowa Press]], Iowa City, 1999, p.77. {{ISBN|0-87745-697-6}}</ref> Indebted to [[Jules Verne]] and [[H. G. Wells]], Macedonski also wrote a number of [[science fiction]] stories, including the 1913 ''Oceania-Pacific-Dreadnought'', which depicts civilization on the verge of a crisis.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.421-421, 435-436</ref> The gigantic commercial ship is maintained by a banker's union, and designed to grant travelers access to every pleasure imaginable; this causes the working-class inhabited cities on the continent to fall into a state of neglect and permanent violence, the climax of the story occurring with the bankers' decision to destroy their creation.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, 435-436</ref> ''Oceania-Pacific-Dreadnought'' is noted for anticipating [[television]], the ship being equipped with electrically-operated "large and clear mirrors" that display "images from various parts of the Earth".<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, 435</ref> Macedonski was by then interested in the development of cinema, and authored a [[silent film]] screenplay based on ''Comment on devient riche et puissant''.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.448</ref>
===Final transition=== [[File:Frederic Leighton - Dante in Exile.jpg|thumb|300px|''Dante in Exile'', 1864 painting by [[Frederic Leighton, 1st Baron Leighton|Lord Leighton]]]]
Late in his life, Macedonski had come to reject Symbolist tenets, defining them as "imbecilities" designed for "the uncultured".<ref name="Călinescu, p.526" /> ''Ultima verba'', the very last poems to be written by him, show him coming to terms with himself, and are treasured for their serene or intensely joyous vision of life and human accomplishment.<ref>Anghelescu, p.29-31; Călinescu, p.527; Vianu, Vol.II, p.385</ref> The [[Rondel (poem)|rondels]] written at this stage, known collectively as ''[[Poema rondelurilor]]'', are one of the first instances where the technique is used locally. Like those written previously by ''Literatorul''{{'}}s Pavelescu and [[Alexandru Obedenaru]], they are based on an earlier motif present in Macedonski's work, that of recurring refrains.<ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.418-419">Vianu, Vol.II, p.418-419</ref> Many of the pieces document the poet's final discoveries. One of them is ''Rondelul crinilor'' ("The Rondel of the Lilies"), which proclaims fragrances as the source of beatitude: ''În crini e beția cea rară'', "In lilies one finds that exceptional drunkenness".<ref name="aonarco22" /><ref name="Călinescu, p.527"/> According to [[Ștefan Cazimir]], ''Rondelul orașului mic'' ("The Rondel of the Small Town") shows a "likable wave of irony and self-irony", and the poet himself coming to terms with "the existence of a world who ignores him."<ref name="stcantxvii" /> Proof of his combativeness was still to be found in ''Rondelul contimporanilor'' ("The Rondel of the Contemporaries").<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.473-474</ref>
The poet's take on life is also outlined in his final play, ''Moartea lui Dante''. Călinescu writes that, by then, Macedonski was "obsessed" with the ''[[Divine Comedy]]''.<ref name="Călinescu, p.528">Călinescu, p.528</ref> Macedonski identifies with his hero, [[Dante Aligheri]], and formulates his own poetic testament while identifying [[World War I]] Romania with the medieval [[Republic of Florence]].<ref>Anghelescu, p.13; Călinescu, p.523, 529; Vianu, Vol.II, p.474-479</ref> Tudor Vianu remarks: "In Dante's great self-pride, Macedonski found his own."<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.476</ref> He sees the play as the best such work to have been produced by Macedonski,<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.478-479, 482</ref> whereas Călinescu deems it "puerile".<ref name="Călinescu, p.529"/> Zamfir believes ''Moartea...'' to be a significant text in Macedonski's bibliography, "one of the first samples of Romanian Symbolist theater", and as such indebted mainly to Maeterlinck.<ref name="mzrivalul"/> Vianu argues that the play may document the Romanian writer's late rejection of France, through the protagonist's statement: "the French are a gentle people, but their soul is different from mine."<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.477</ref>
A number of rondels show Macedonski's late fascination with the [[Far East]], China and Japan. George Călinescu believes that this is to be understood as one item in a large [[antithesis]], the other being Decadent Paris, which one rondel describes as "hell".<ref name="Călinescu, p.528" /> The Orient, viewed as the space of serenity, is believed by Macedonski to be peopled by toy-like women and absent [[opium]]-smokers, and to be kept orderly by a stable [[meritocracy]].<ref name="Călinescu, p.528" /> The Chinese-themed poem ''Tsing-Ly-Tsi'', which Cazimir notes for its discreet, "almost imperceptible", humor, reads: {{Verse translation| {{lang|ro|Tsing-Ly-Tsi stă-n prispa de-aur, Cu ochi mici ca de ghierlan, Sub de-argint frunzos tezaur, Casa e de porțelan.}}<ref name="stcantxvii" /> | Tsing-Ly-Tsi sits on the golden porch, With his eyes as small as those of mice, Under the silvery, leafy, treasure, His house is porcelain-like.}}
==Legacy==
===Macedonski's school and its early impact=== [[File:Alexandru Macedonski, Alexis & Oreste Georgescu.JPG|thumb|250px|Alexandru Macedonski (seated, to the right) facing [[Oreste Georgescu]]. [[Alexis Macedonski]] standing]]
Alexandru Macedonski repeatedly expressed the thought that, unlike his contemporaries, posterity would judge him a great poet.<ref>Călinescu, p.519, 520-521, 523, 527, 529; Vianu, Vol.III, p.434-435</ref> With the exception of [[Mihail Dragomirescu]], conservative literary critics tended to ignore Macedonski while he was alive. The first such figure was ''Junimea''{{'}}s [[Titu Maiorescu]], who believed him to be a minor author, referring to him only a couple of times in his books and usually ridiculing him in his articles.<ref name="mzrivalul"/><ref>Călinescu, p.407, 412; Ornea, p.117; Vianu, Vol.II, p.243, 356</ref> One of these texts, the 1886 essay ''Poeți și critici'' ("Poets and Critics"), spoke of Macedonski as having "vitiated" poetry, a notion he also applied to [[Constantin D. Aricescu]] and [[Aron Densușianu]].<ref>Ornea, p.117</ref> Especially radical pronouncements were left by the traditionalist authors [[Ilarie Chendi]] and [[Nicolae Iorga]]. Chendi wrote of Macedonski being "the caricature of a man", having "a feverish mind" and being motivated by "the brutal instinct of revenge".<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.391. According to Călinescu (p.638): "Chendi lacks even the faintest intuition of Macedonski's poetry."</ref> Iorga, who became better known as a historian, later retracted some of the statements he had made against the poet during the 1890s.<ref name="Anghelescu, p.15"/> Among the younger prominent traditionalist writers was the [[Transylvania]]n-born [[Lucian Blaga]], who may have purposefully avoided Macedonski during his first visit to Bucharest in 1920.<ref>Balotă, p.42</ref> Although more sympathetic to the Symbolist author, both Dragomirescu and [[Gheorghe Adamescu]] tended to describe him as exclusively the product of French and Decadent literature,<ref name="Anghelescu, p.15" /> while Dragomirescu's disciple [[Ion Trivale]] denied all merit to Macedonski's literature.<ref>Călinescu, p.644</ref>
According to Tudor Vianu, Macedonski's intellectual friends (among them [[Anghel Demetriescu]], [[George Ionescu-Gion]], [[Bonifaciu Florescu]], [[Grigore Tocilescu]] and [[V. A. Urechia]]) were largely responsible for passing down "a better and truer image of the abused poet."<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.388-389</ref> It was also due to Dragomirescu that ''Noaptea de decemvrie'' was included in a literature textbook for final grade high school students, which some argue is the poet's first-ever presence in the [[Education in Romania|Romanian curriculum]].<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.380. According to Anghelescu (p.15), this was preceded by an 1891 textbook published by educator E. Manliu, which introduced Macedonski through his ''Calul arabului''.</ref> According to historian Lucian Nastasă, the poet's wife Ana Rallet behaved like an "excellent secretary" while Macedonski was still alive, and thereafter helped sort and edit his manuscript while maintaining "an actual cult" for her husband.<ref>Nastasă, p.146</ref>
Macedonski's [[Cosmopolitanism|cosmopolitan]] circle was the center of a literary alternative to the prevailing conservatism and Eminescu-like traditionalism of the day, the latter tendency being grouped around ''[[Sămănătorul]]'' magazine for part of Macedonski's lifetime.<ref name="mzrivalul"/><ref>Cernat, p.10-11, 15, 18; Ornea, p.136-137; Sandqvist, p.75, 197, 200, 202</ref> While Macedonski himself maintained his links with Romanticism and Classicism, commentators have retrospectively recognized in him the main person who announced Romania's first wave in [[modernist literature]].<ref name="mzrivalul"/><ref>Anghelescu, p.139-140; Cernat, p.10-11, 15; Krasztev, "From Modernization...", p.334, 338, 343; Sandqvist, p.197, 200; Vianu, Vol.II, p.483</ref> Many first-generation disciples were to part with his guidelines early on, either by radicalizing their Symbolism or by stepping out of its confines. [[Traian Demetrescu]] was one of the first to do so, focusing on his commitment to [[socialism]]—Vianu notes that the split took place "without coldness and the heart's versatility" on Macedonski's part.<ref>Vianu, Vol. II, p.391</ref> Literary researcher [[Lidia Bote]] argues that it was Petică who first illustrated mature Symbolism, emancipating himself from Macedonski's [[Eclecticism|eclectic]] tendencies after 1902.<ref>Cernat, p.15</ref> By that time, the Symbolist authors [[Dimitrie Anghel]] and [[N. D. Cocea]] used Macedonski's fantasy prose as an inspiration for their own, and [[N. Davidescu]] was borrowing from his mystical discourse.<ref>Călinescu, p.690, 697, 919</ref> The pictorial and joyous elements in Macedonski's poems were also serving to inspire Stamatiad, [[Eugeniu Ștefănescu-Est]] and [[Horia Furtună]].<ref>Călinescu, p.700-701, 727</ref> In the early stages of his career, [[Ion Pillat]] wrote pieces which echo his master's choice of [[Exoticism|exotic]] themes.<ref>Călinescu, p.857-858</ref> A more discreet legacy of Macedonski's ideas was also preserved inside the conservative and traditionalist camps. Although his separation from ''Literatorul'' was drastic, and led him to rally with ''Junimea'', [[Duiliu Zamfirescu]] built on some elements borrowed from the magazine's ideology, incorporating them into his literary vision.<ref>Ornea, p.263-264; Vianu, Vol.II, p.432</ref>
Many of Macedonski's most devoted disciples, whom he himself had encouraged, have been rated by various critics as secondary or mediocre. This is the case of [[Theodor Cornel]] (who made his name as an art critic),<ref>Cernat, p.45-46</ref> [[Mircea Demetriade]],<ref name="aonarco22" /><ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.388"</ref> [[Oreste Georgescu]],<ref>Călinescu, p.652-653</ref> [[Alexandru Obedenaru]],<ref name="aonarco22" /><ref name="Vianu, Vol.II, p.418-419" /> Stoenescu, Stamatiad, [[Carol Scrob]], [[Dumitru Karnabatt]] and [[Donar Munteanu]].<ref>Călinescu, p.523, 531-532, 701-702</ref> Another such minor author was the self-styled "[[hermeticist]]" [[Alexandru Petroff]], who expanded on Macedonski's ideas about esoteric knowledge.<ref name="Cernat, p.11"/>
Macedonski's eldest son [[Alexis Macedonski|Alexis]] continued to pursue a career as a painter. His son [[Soare Macedonski|Soare]] followed in his footsteps, receiving acclaim from art critics of the period. Soare's short career ended in 1928, before he turned nineteen, but his works have been featured in several retrospective exhibitions, including one organized by Alexis.<ref>[[Nicolae Tonitza]], "Cronica plastică (Despre cei mai tineri: Soare Al. Macedonski.—Adina Paula Moscu.—Titina Căpitănescu.—Lazăr Zim)", in ''[[Viața Românească]]'', Nr.4/1929</ref><ref name="tosoare">{{ro icon}} [[Tudor Octavian]], [http://www.zf.ro/ziarul-de-duminica/soare-macedonski-1910-1928-2981174/ "Soare Macedonski (1910-1928)"], in ''[[Ziarul Financiar]]'', June 10, 2003</ref> Alexis later experimented with [[scenic design]] as an assistant to French filmmaker [[René Clair]]; his later life, shrouded in mystery and intrigue, led him to a career in [[Italian fascism|Fascist Italy]] and [[Francoist Spain]].<ref name="tosoare" /> Another of Alexandru Macedonski's sons, Nikita, was also a poet and painter. For a while in the 1920s, he edited the literary supplement of ''[[Universul]]'' newspaper.<ref>{{ro icon}} Emil Manu, [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/MANUoct.html "Melancolia agrestă (Zaharia Stancu)"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', October 2002</ref> Two years after her father's death, Anna Macedonski married poet [[Mihail Celarianu]].<ref name="Călinescu, p.960">Călinescu, p.960</ref>
In addition to his polemical portrayals in works by Alecsandri, Eminescu and Caragiale, Macedonski's career was an inspiration for various authors. His image acquired mythical proportions for his followers. Like Demetrescu, many of them left memoirs on Macedonski which were published before or after his death. His admirers were writing poetry about him as early as 1874,<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.342</ref> and, in 1892, [[Cincinat Pavelescu]] published a rhapsodizing portrait of Macedonski as "the Artist".<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.387</ref> Pavelescu, Dragoslav and Petică paid homage to the writer by leaving recollections which describe him as a devoted and considerate friend.<ref>Vianu, Vol.II, p.390</ref> In contrast, traditionalist poet [[Alexandru Vlahuță]] authored an 1889 [[sketch story]] in which Macedonski (referred to as ''Polidor'') is the object of derision.<ref>Călinescu, p.558; Vianu, Vol.II, p.386-387. Vlahuță's articles include several other attacks on Macedonski (Anghelescu, p.15).</ref>
===Late recognition=== Actual recognition of the poet as a classic came only in the [[interwar period]]. A final volume of never before published poems, ''[[Poema rondelurilor]]'', saw print in 1927.<ref name="Anghelescu, p.13"/> Macedonski's work was analyzed and popularized by a new generation of critics, among them Vianu and George Călinescu. The post-''Junimist'' modernist critic [[Eugen Lovinescu]] also commented favorably on Macedonski's work,<ref name="elrseisl" /><ref>Anghelescu, p.16</ref> but overall, Călinescu asserts, his opinions on the subject gave little insight into what he actually thought about the poet.<ref>Călinescu, p.801</ref> He also recounts that Macedonski himself treated Lovinescu with disdain, and once called him "a canary".<ref name="Călinescu, p.523"/>
The emerging [[avant-garde]], although originating from Symbolism, progressively took its distance from ''Literatorul''{{'}}s legacy. Initially, Macedonski's contribution to [[experimental literature]] was continued within formal Symbolism by his disciples Demetriade, [[Iuliu Cezar Săvescu]]<ref>Vianu, Vol.III, p.374</ref> and [[Ion Minulescu]].<ref>Sandqvist, p.202, 384; Vianu, Vol.III, p.374</ref> The latter was particularly indebted to Macedonski in matters of vision and language.<ref>Călinescu, p.693, 697; Vianu, Vol.III, p.380</ref> In 1904, [[Tudor Arghezi]] also left behind the ''Literatorul'' circle and its tenets, eventually arriving to the fusion of modernist, traditionalist and [[avant-garde]] elements.<ref name="vztcron" /><ref>Balotă, p.10, 16-34; Cernat, p.15</ref> However, he remained indebted to Macedonski's example in his descriptive prose.<ref>Vianu, Vol.III, p.451</ref> The 1912 ''[[Simbolul]]'' magazine, which moved between conventional Symbolism and the emerging avant-garde, also published an [[Imagism|Imagist]]-inspired [[parody]] of ''Noaptea de mai'', signed by [[Adrian Maniu]].<ref>Cernat, p.50</ref> A co-founder of [[Dada]]ism during the late 1910s, [[Tristan Tzara]] is believed by Swedish researcher [[Tom Sandqvist]] to have been inspired more or less directly by Macedonski, and in particular by the latter's thoughts on the relation between absurdity and poetry.<ref>Sandqvist, p.197, 199, 200, 207</ref> In his debut poems, [[Benjamin Fondane|Benjamin Fondane-Barbu Fundoianu]] occasionally followed Macedonski,<ref>[[Mircea Martin]], preface to [[Benjamin Fondane|B. Fundoianu]], ''Poezii'', [[Editura Minerva]], Bucharest, 1978, p.XI. {{OCLC|252065138}}</ref> but, by 1920, stated that the Symbolist doyen merely imitated French models to the point of "parasitism".<ref>Cernat, p.208-209; Răileanu & Carassou, p.7</ref>
Several avant-garde authors returned to Macedonski's literary guidelines by the late 1920s, as they themselves grew more moderate. This was the case of Maniu and [[Ion Vinea]], both of whom published prose works in the line of ''Thalassa''.<ref name="Cernat, p.184">Cernat, p.184</ref> The same work is also believed to have influenced two non-avant-garde authors, Davidescu and [[Mateiu Caragiale]], who remained close to the tenets Symbolism.<ref name="Cernat, p.184" /> Mateiu was the illegitimate son of Ion Luca Caragiale, but, Vianu notes, could withstand comparisons with his father's rival: the eccentricities were complementary, although Mateiu Caragiale shied away from public affairs.<ref>Vianu, Vol.III, p.171</ref> In the same post-Symbolist generation, Celarianu (Macedonski's posthumous son-in-law),<ref name="Călinescu, p.960" /> [[George Bacovia]]<ref name="mzrivalul"/><ref>Sandqvist, p.208-209; Vianu, Vol.III, p.388</ref> and [[Păstorel Teodoreanu]]<ref name="arteodo"/><ref>Călinescu, p.779</ref> also built on Macedonski's legacy, being later joined in this by the [[Bessarabia]]n linguist [[Eugenio Coșeriu]] (who, in his early poetic career, imitated Macedonski's rondel style).<ref>{{ro icon}} Ion Țurcanu, [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/TURCANUiun6.html "Poezia basarabeană din interbelic"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', June 2006</ref> In the late 1920s, when their form of modern [[psalms]] inspired [[Albanians of Romania|Albanian-Romanian]] poet [[Aleksander Stavre Drenova]], Macedonski and Arghezi both made an indirect impact on [[Albanian literature]].<ref>[[Robert Elsie]], ''Albanian Literature: A Short History'', [[I.B. Tauris]], Centre for Albanian Studies, London & New York, 2005, p.104. {{ISBN|1-84511-031-5}}</ref>
Macedonski's status as one of Romanian literature's greats was consolidated later in the 20th century. By this time, ''Noaptea de decemvrie'' had become one of the most recognizable literary works to be taught in Romanian schools.<ref name="elrseisl" /> During the first years of [[Communist Romania]], the [[Socialist realism in Romania|Socialist Realist current]] condemned Symbolism (''see [[Censorship in Communist Romania]]''), but spoke favorably of Macedonski's critique of the [[bourgeoisie]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ion Simuț]], [http://www.romlit.ro/index.pl/canonul_literar_proletcultist "Canonul literar proletcultist"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 27/2008</ref> A while after this episode, [[Marin Sorescu]], one of the best-known modernist poets of his generation, wrote a homage-parody of the ''Nights'' cycle. Included in the volume ''Singur între poeți'' ("Alone among Poets"), it is seen by critic [[Mircea Scarlat]] as Sorescu's most representative such pieces.<ref>[[Mircea Scarlat]], preface to [[Marin Sorescu]], ''Drumul'', [[Editura Minerva]], Bucharest, 1984, p.XI, XIII, XIX, XXV. {{OCLC|17114213}}</ref> Also then, ''Noaptea de decemvrie'' partly inspired [[Ștefan Augustin Doinaș]]' [[ballad]] ''[[Mistrețul cu colți de argint]]''.<ref name="elrseisl" />
In the 1990s, [[Ștefan Agopian]] took the ''Nights'' cycle as inspiration for an [[Erotic literature|erotic]] short story,<ref>{{ro icon}} UN Cristian, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/%C4%B9%C5%BEtefan-Agopian-Cind-citeam-o-carte-buna-uitam-sa-mi-fac-lectiile*articleID_20516-articles_details.html "Ștefan Agopian: 'Cînd citeam o carte bună, uitam să-mi fac lecțiile!' "], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 443, October 2008</ref> while [[Pavel Șușară]] adapted his rondels to a modernized setting.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Luminița Marcu]], [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Poezii-cu-dichis-de-Pavel-Susara*articleID_2149-articles_details.html "Poezii cu dichis de Pavel Șușară"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 70, June 2001</ref> Macedonski's prose also influenced younger writers such as [[Angelo Mitchievici]]<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ioan Stanomir]], [http://www.revista22.ro/gr259dini-suspendate-7139.html "Grădini suspendate"], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 1029, November 2009</ref> and [[Anca Maria Mosora]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Bianca Burța-Cernat, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/index.html/articles|details?articleID=14694 "Un exercițiu ratat de virtuozitate"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 305, January 2006</ref> In neighboring [[Moldova]], Macedonski influenced the [[Neosymbolism]] of [[Aureliu Busuioc]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Eugen Lungu]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20110721123410/http://www.sud-est.md/numere/20081202/article_2/ "După aniversare"], in ''[[Revista Sud-Est]]'', Nr. 4/2008</ref> A magazine by the name of ''Literatorul'', which claims to represent the legacy of Macedonski's publication, was founded in Romania in 1991, being edited by writers Sorescu, [[Fănuș Neagu]] and [[Mircea Micu]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://literatorul.wordpress.com/ ''Literatorul''] official site; retrieved November 3, 2008</ref> In 2006, the [[Romanian Academy]] granted posthumous membership to Alexandru Macedonski.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.acad.ro/membri_ar/pag_membri_pm.htm ''Membrii post-mortem al Academiei Române''], at the [[Romanian Academy]] site; retrieved November 3, 2008</ref>
Macedonski's poems had a sizable impact on Romania's [[popular culture]]. During communism, ''Noaptea de mai'' was the basis for a successful musical adaptation, composed by [[Marian Nistor]] and sung by [[Mirabela Dauer]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://colectie.jurnalul.ro/articole/108612/ "Copilul cu vocea poleită"], in ''[[Jurnalul Național]]'', November 12, 2007</ref> [[Tudor Gheorghe]], a singer-songwriter inspired by [[American folk music revival|American folk revival]], also used some of Macedonski's texts as lyrics to his melodies.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.jurnalul.ro/index.php?section=rubrici&article_id=20201 "Concert - Toamna lui Tudor Gheorghe"], in ''[[Jurnalul Național]]'', May 31, 2006</ref> In the 2000s, the refrain of ''Noaptea de mai'' was mixed into a ''[[Manele|manea]]'' parody by [[Adrian Copilul Minune]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Radu Pavel Gheo]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20071202101333/http://www.revista22.ro/html/index.php?art=2398&nr=2006-01-25 "Un gen muzical proteic"], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 829, January 2006</ref>
===Portrayals, visual tributes and landmarks=== [[File:Stamps of Romania, 2004-060.jpg|thumb|Macedonski's portrait on a Romanian [[postage stamp]] (2004)]]
Although his poetic theories were largely without echoes in [[Art of Romania|Romanian art]],<ref>Vida, p.55</ref> Macedonski captured the interest of several modern artists, including, early on, cartoonist [[Nicolae Petrescu Găină]].<ref>Paul Rezeanu, "Caricaturistul N.S. Petrescu-Găină", in ''[[Magazin Istoric]]'', August 2008, p.61, 62</ref> Alongside other writers who visited Terasa Oteteleșanu, Macedonski was notably portrayed the drawings of celebrated Romanian artist [[Iosif Iser]].<ref name="micafene" /> He is also depicted in a 1918 [[lithograph]] by [[Jean Alexandru Steriadi]], purportedly Steriadi's only Symbolist work.<ref>Vida, p.63</ref> ''Thalassa, Le Calvaire de feu'' inspired a series of [[relief]]s, designed by Alexis Macedonski and hosted in his father's house in [[Dorobanți]].<ref name="Vianu, Vol.III, p.352"/> During the 1910s, busts of him were completed by two sculptors, [[Alexandru Severin]] and [[Friedrich Storck]], one of Storck's variants being hosted by the [[Ioan Cantacuzino]] collection.<ref name="vztcron" /> In 1919, [[Theodor Burcă]] was also inspired to complete another bust, and, during [[World War II]], was commissioned by [[Mayor of Bucharest]] [[Ion Rășcanu]] to build a Macedonski Monument in the [[Grădina Icoanei]] park, but this was never completed.<ref name="vztcron" /> [[Constantin Piliuță]], a painter active in the second half of the 20th century, made Macedonski the subject of a portrait in series dedicated to Romanian cultural figures (also depicted were [[Nicolae Iorga]], [[Ștefan Luchian]] and Vianu).<ref>Vasile Drăguț, Vasile Florea, [[Dan Grigorescu]], Marin Mihalache, ''Pictura românească în imagini'', [[Editura Meridiane]], Bucharest, 1970, p.312. {{OCLC|5717220}}</ref> In 1975, a bust of Macedonski, the work of [[Constantin Foamete]], was unveiled in [[Craiova]].<ref name="vztcron" />
Of Macedonski's numerous residences, the one in Dorobanți was demolished when the [[Bucharest Academy of Economic Studies|Academy of Economic Studies]] (ASE) was expanded.<ref name="vztcron" /><ref name="pippididilema" /> A commemorative plaque was later put up near the spot.<ref name="vztcron" /> Macedonski's childhood home in [[Goiești]] passed into state property under communism, and was in turn a school, a community home and a Macedonski Museum, before falling into neglect after the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Aldezir Marin, [http://www.gds.ro/Viata%20satului/2006-05-27/O+ruina+incarcata+de+istorie "O ruină încarcată de istorie"], in ''[[Gazeta de Sud]]'', May 27, 2006</ref> Several streets named in honor of Alexandru Macedonski, notably in Bucharest (by the ASE), Craiova, [[Cluj-Napoca]] and [[Timișoara]].

The '''Alice Davis Hitchcock Book Award''', established in 1949, by the [[Society of Architectural Historians]], annually recognizes "the most distinguished work of scholarship in the history of architecture published by a North American scholar." {{ref|sah-website}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sah.org/conferences-and-programs/award-programs/publication-awards|title=SAH Publication Awards|website=www.sah.org|access-date=2018-01-08}}</ref> The oldest of the six different publication awards given annually by the Society, it is named after the mother of architectural historian [[Henry-Russell Hitchcock]].

[[File:Beit lessin.jpg|thumb|Beit Lessin Theater]] '''Beit Lessin Theater''' ({{lang-he-n|תיאטרון בית ליסין}}, [[Transliteration|translit]]: ''Teatron Bet Lessin'') is a theater in [[Tel Aviv]], [[Israel]]. ==History== Established in 1978 by [[Yaakov Agmon]] for the [[Histadrut]],<ref>Linda Ben-Zvi. ''Theater in Israel''. University of Michigan Press, 1996. {{ISBN|0-472-10607-4}}. pg.22. See [https://books.google.com/books?id=v_tXKyDG5j4C&printsec=frontcover&cd=1&source=gbs_ViewAPI&hl=en#v=onepage&q=beit%20lessin&f=false ''Theater in Israel'' on Google Books ]</ref>
Over the years the theater has shown over a thousand contemporary American and European plays, as well as original productions. In 1993, [[Zippi Pines]] started managing the theater. It was separated from the Histadrut and started showing mostly original Israeli material reflecting the political and social situation in Israel.
In 2003, the theater moved from Lessin House to the old residence of the Cameri Theater after it was remodeled. This venue having more seats allowed larger and more expensive plays to be produced, such as [[Chicago (musical)|Chicago]] and [[Guys and Dolls (musical)|Guys and Dolls]].
The theater's production "Mikveh" won the Israeli Theater Prize in 2005. ==See also== *[[Theater of Israel]]

A '''Bit-hilani''' ([[Akkadian language|Akkadian]]: ''Bīt-Ḫilāni'', meaning 'house of pillars') is an ancient architectural type of palace. It seems to have become popular at the end of the tenth and during the ninth century BCE during the early [[Iron Age]] in northern Syria although it may have originated as early as the [[Bronze Age]]. Contemporary records call it a Hittite-style palace, probably after the [[Neo-Hittite]] kingdoms of northern Syria. == Individual examples == [[File:Entrance of the National Museum Aleppo Syria.jpg|thumb|Entrance of the National Museum Aleppo, a reconstruction of the entrance to Kapara's palace at Tell Halaf]] The oldest excavated building described as ''Hilani'' by its excavator [[Sir Leonard Woolley]] is a palaceA [https://web.archive.org/web/20120426001717/https://feldman.berkeley.edu:453/?course=nes190a&do=detail&imgid=00535 plan] of the Palace of Niqmepa at Tell Atchana, the ancient Alalakh. in level IV at [[Alalakh]] dated to the 15th century BCE. The palace is thought to have been built by [[Niqmepa, King of Alalakh|Niqmepa]], a son of [[Idrimi]] of the royal family of the [[Amorite]] state of [[Yamhad]] based in [[Halab]]. A building at the citadel (Büyükkale) of the Hittite capital [[Hattusa]] may also have been of the hilani type.The detached building (labeled as building E on most plans) lies near the north west corner of the palace area of the citadel, between the large reception hall and the more private building in the northernmost corner of the citadel. It does not seem to have been incorporated in the court systems and may thus have served as a more private reception building. During excavations an archive was found within the building. The [https://archive.is/20120802185613/http://www.hattuscha.de/English/kingspalace.htm plan of the building] seems rather symmetrical and is more similar to those unearthed in Sam'al and Carchemish than for example the palace of Kapara at Guzana. See also [http://www.atamanhotel.com/whc/hattusa-buyukkale.html this map] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513122455/http://www.atamanhotel.com/whc/hattusa-buyukkale.html |date=May 13, 2008 }} of the acropolis of Hattusa with a detailed description of the buildings and areas. As most of the structures on the citadel underwent considerable rebuilding during the reign of [[Tudhaliya IV]] (ca. 1237 BCE–1209 BCE), it is usually dated to the 13th century BCE.See the paragraph [http://www.hattuscha.de/English/cityhistory2.htm "V. The Period of the Hittite Empire"] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120803000911/http://www.hattuscha.de/English/cityhistory2.htm |date=2012-08-03 }}. [[Kapara]], king of the [[Neo-Hittite|Hittite]]{{Cite book|title=Anatolian Studies, Volumes 5-6|last=|first=|publisher=British Institute of Archaeology at Ankara|year=1955|isbn=|location=|pages=82}} kingdom of [[Bit Bahiani]] in the 10th or 9th century BCE, built himself a palace of this style in his capital at [[Guzana]] (Tell Halaf). The palace,A [https://web.archive.org/web/20120426001744/https://feldman.berkeley.edu:453/?course=nes120a&do=detail&imgid=00546 plan] of the palace with the adjoining Skorpians Gate. Illustrations from "The Art and Architecture of the Ancient Orient." 5th ed. New Haven: Yale University Press, 1996 by Henri Frankfort. with a rich decoration of statues and relief orthostats, was excavated by [[Max von Oppenheim]] in 1911. Some of the finds were taken to [[Berlin]], and most of them destroyed when von Oppenheim's private museum was hit during a bombing raid in November 1943. The [[National Museum of Aleppo]] has reconstructed the pillared portico in front of its entrance. Other buildings of this type have been excavated among others at [[Tell Tayinat]],Brief [https://www.utoronto.ca/tap/past.htm description] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090419221106/http://www.utoronto.ca/tap/past.htm |date=April 19, 2009 }} of the construction periods the found hilani type buildings belonged to, with the oldest (Building XIII) dated to around 950 BCE. [[Qatna]], [[Sam'al]], [[Sakçagözü]], [[Carchemish]], [[Tell Seh Hamad]],[http://www.schechhamad.de/ Website] of the excavation (in german). The Hilani (building F) was found in the northwest corner of the lower city, integrated into a larger palace complex. It is [http://www.schechhamad.de/ausgrabung/grabungsabschnitt_nordostecke.php dated] to the 8th century BCE. maybe [[Kinet Höyük]] An entrance excavated in 2007, formed by two wide steps framed by two posts is compared to the Bit-hilani style of the Late Bronze Age by the excavators. A restored view is shown on [http://cat.une.edu.au/page/kinet%20hoyuk this page (fig.6)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719023206/http://cat.une.edu.au/page/kinet%20hoyuk |date=July 19, 2008 }} at the "[http://cat.une.edu.au/ Current Archeology in Turkey] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215095310/http://cat.une.edu.au/ |date=February 15, 2009 }}" site. and at [[Emar]].A [http://www.uni-tuebingen.de/emar/en/excavation.html hilani type palace (Palace A)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080307083433/http://www.uni-tuebingen.de/emar/en/excavation.html |date=March 7, 2008 }} is said to lie on or near what is now a small island in [[Lake Assad]], north of the upper town with the temples. Marked with the number 10 on this [http://www.uni-tuebingen.de/emar/en/research.html map] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080307074956/http://www.uni-tuebingen.de/emar/en/research.html |date=March 7, 2008 }} of the site. When claiming to have built in the style of a hilani, most builders probably referred to the pillared portico with [[antechamber]] such as: [[Sargon II]], King of [[Assyria]] 722–705 BCE, at his new city of [[Dur-Sharrukin]], begun in 713 BCE. An isolated building of which not much is known yet has been located in the western corner of the palace terrace. It may be a candidad [http://www.louvre.fr/llv/oeuvres/detail_notice.jsp?CONTENT%3C%3Ecnt_id=10134198673225256&CURRENT_LLV_NOTICE%3C%3Ecnt_id=10134198673225256&FOLDER%3C%3Efolder_id=9852723696500800&bmLocale=en Description]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} of the site the relief "[http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Genie_poppy_Dur_Sharrukin_Louvre_AO19869.jpg Genius holding a poppy flower]", now at the [[Louvre]], was found at. for the building he mentions in his founding text.[http://archaeotype.dalton.org/library/oldsite/eighth.html Translation] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725215249/http://archaeotype.dalton.org/library/oldsite/eighth.html |date=July 25, 2011 }} and plans of the excavated parts of the palace of Sargon II at Dur-Sharrukin.
"A portico, patterned after the Hittite palace, which in the language of Amurru they call a bit-hilani, I built in front of the palaces' gates."
[[Sennacherib]], King of [[Assyria]] (704–681 BC), claims to have done some building in [[Niniveh]] in the style of a bit-hilani. Nothing similar to a ''hilani'' has to date been identified without doubt at his palace, known today as the South-West Palace in Niniveh, finished in 694 BCE. The building in question may not have been found yet. == Description == The major feature for a visitor would have been the monumental entrance [[loggia]] or [[portico]] with columnsPeter M. M. G. Akkermans, Glenn M. Schwartz, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=_4oqvpAHDEoC&pg=PA368&lpg=PA368&dq=Bit-hilani&source=bl&ots=0kkl53LDER&sig=_l6ci23AWxY9FUTNdNw7q8Ie2Qw&hl=de&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result#PPA370,M1 The Archaeology of Syria: From Complex Hunter-gatherers to Early Urban Societies (c. 16,000-300 BC)]'', Cambridge University Press, 2003, {{ISBN|0-521-79666-0}}, {{ISBN|978-0-521-79666-8}}, pages 368-370 flanked by large massive parts of the building and approached by a broad but relative low flight of steps. On one side a stairway to the upper parts would reside in one of these block like structures.Historical dictionary of the Hittites by Charles Allen Burney, Scarecrow Press, 2004, [https://books.google.com/books?id=azPl5Jzv930C&pg=PA42&lpg=PA42&dq=hilani+aleppo&source=bl&ots=3_ajarZ0Qi&sig=b-QTpvTFnjISpTpaLExQOitUUmk&hl=de&ei=ZPi8TsewDK_a4QSxlKjFBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&sqi=2&ved=0CGAQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=hilani%20aleppo&f=false page 41-2] (google books link) Straight ahead one would enter the great hall, where one would have to turn by 90° to see the throne in the far end of the hall. The overall plan of the building would be rectangular with the large hall in the middle surrounded on all sides by the other much narrower rooms.Comparable [https://books.google.com/books?id=oYearm8YobQC&pg=PA145&lpg=PA145&dq=%2B%22bit+hilani%22+-Assi+%22confronting+the+past%22&source=bl&ots=YpOVpJm7rs&sig=IgKON32uqrZETTrd5vEa9WIE2AU&hl=de&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result#PPA145,M1 plans] of the hilani type buildings at the top on page 146 (fig.1 ""Tell Ta'yinat", "Tell Halaf", "Zinjirli" and "Sakje Guezi") in ''Podium Structures with Lateral Access'' by Ilan Sharon and Anabel Zarzecki-Peleg in ''"Confronting the Past: Archaeological and Historical Essays on Ancient Israel in Honor of William G. Dever"'', 2006, {{ISBN|1-57506-117-1}}, {{ISBN|978-1-57506-117-7}} This type of design with a large central space surrounded by a double wall with smaller rooms taking up the space within the walls may be based on designs first used in the late [[Ubaid period]] in southern Mesopotamia such as the [[Ubaid house]]. Pillared porticos as gates or grand entrances were used by several cultures of the Bronze Age around the eastern Mediterranean sea. The examples of the Hittites and the Myceneans may be the best known. Through the [[megaron]]s and [[propylaea]] of the [[Mycenaean Greece|mycenaean]] palaces the style may have lived into classical Greek designs. The late ''hilani'' of the levant may well be the combination of the old broad room concept with a Hittite-style portico. In recent traditional architecture it may have a late resemblance in the design of the [[liwan]] house. == References == {{Reflist|33em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bit-Hilani}} [[Category:10th-century BC architecture]] [[Category:Ancient Near East art and architecture]] [[Category:House types]]

The '''California Institute for Yiddish Culture and Language''' (CYCL) started in 1999 and serves as a multi-generational center for the teaching, promotion, celebration and learning of [[Yiddish]] in all of its embodiments, with an emphasis on the arts and other areas that influence the cultural formations that inform its existence. The institute owes its establishment to Miriam Koral, who is the Founding Director, and who, as a Yiddish instructor at [[UCLA]] and native Yiddish speaker, created the center and community that brings world-renowned Yiddish authors, playwrights, musicians, poets, artists and others to the [[Los Angeles]] area. <ref>{{cite web|title=The Routledge Handbook of Heritage Language Education|page=459|url=https://books.google.com.vn/books?id=Ri8lDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA459&lpg=PA459&dq=california+institute+for+yiddish+culture+and+language&source=bl&ots=RgSYPhwZW2&sig=tUl7Vn5vm4f8-2XtadQKBPT-qPw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjYq6nN9sfXAhUCkJQKHbUPD5M4ChDoAQgvMAI#v=onepage&q=california%20institute%20for%20yiddish%20culture%20and%20language&f=false|accessdate=18 November 2017}}</ref>

'''Color-blocking''' is thought of as the exploration of taking colors that are opposites on the color wheel and pairing them together to make interesting and complementary color combinations.<ref name="A Brief History of Color-blocking">{{cite web|title=A Brief History of Color-blocking|url=http://blog.blisshomeanddesign.com/2015/06/15/building-blocks-a-brief-history-of-color-blocking/|website=Bliss by Design|accessdate=18 October 2015}}</ref> It is commonly associated in fashion as a trend that originated from the artwork of Dutch painter, [[Piet Mondrian]]. However, other experts argue whether his artwork is the true origin of color-blocking.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ellenduffer.com/2012/03/23/origin-of-the-trend-color-blocking/|title=Origin of the Trend: Color Blocking|first=Ellen|last=Duffer|date=23 March 2012|publisher=}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Mondriaanmode_door_Yves_St_Laurent_(1966).jpg|thumb|Mondrian dresses by Yves Saint Laurent]] It’s widely believed by most historians that [[Piet Mondrian]], a turn of the century artist, whose paintings were a collection of stark lines and flat squares, inspired this current color-blocking trend.<ref name="A Brief History of Color-blocking"/> Mondrian valued simplicity and therefore experimented with how far he could simplify his work, maximizing simplicity while still maintaining recognizable, although abstract, geometric shapes. Mondrian later named this style of painting Neo-Plasticism.<ref name="A Brief History of Color-blocking"/> In Piet Mondrian's Neoplasticism movement, his art directly inspired the fashion world, as well as home décor and baked goods.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.collegefashion.net/inspiration/fashion-inspired-by-art-piet-mondrians-color-blocking/|title=Fashion Inspired by Art: Piet Mondrian's Color Blocking|publisher=}}</ref> Although Mondrian is said to be the key figure of the modern art movement, there are others that believe the credit for this trend lies with [[Georges Seurat]] and [[Claude Monet]].<ref name="A Brief History of Color-blocking"/> However sources report that it is Piet Mondrian who inspired other designers such as [[Yves Saint Laurent (designer)|Yves Saint Laurent]] to create the famous Mondrian Dresses.<ref name="College Fashion">{{cite web|title=Fashion Inspired by Art: Piet Mondrian's Color-blocking|url=http://www.collegefashion.net/inspiration/fashion-inspired-by-art-piet-mondrians-color-blocking/|accessdate=18 October 2015}}</ref> Before Mondrian's aesthetic overtook the fashion world, pop art's materialization in the 50s opened America's eyes to a more vibrant but structured world. [[Pop Art]] incorporated the same clean lines and solid colors that Piet Mondrian's work encompassed. Proponents of the Georges Seurat and Monet origin theory claim that this novel acceptance lead to the color-blocking revolution.<ref name="Origins of Color-blocking">{{cite web|title=Origin of the Trend: Color Blocking|url=http://ellenduffer.com/2012/03/23/origin-of-the-trend-color-blocking/|accessdate=18 October 2015}}</ref> Mondrian's Neo-Plasticism aesthetic evolved through the decades, coming to include aspects such as synthetic color and a strong imposed structure in the 1960s.<ref name="A Brief History of Color-blocking"/> The color-blocking trend took off in the 60s as fashion designers like Yves Saint Laurent adopted this revolutionary aesthetic. It wasn't long before this new trend was reaching as far as London; the youth of London began wearing ensembles that would come to be known as mod fashion.<ref name="A Brief History of Color-blocking"/> Mod fashion much resembled the artistic style of Piet Mondrian; mismatched, solid color separates that were composed of blocks in different hues.
As for today color-blocking is more frequently seen in the home as a latest thing in interior design.<ref name="A Brief History of Color-blocking"/> Although some argue that color-blocking is a thing in the past, high fashion figures and enthusiasts believe that this retro trend continues to thrive as a result of the hipster generation, whom revive the trend and turn it into something seen as fashion-forward.
==Process== In the fashion world, the process of color-blocking refers to wearing blocks of colors. Color-blocking is different than how people usually dress because the colors in the outfit are considered louder, or colors that clash. Fashion figures explain color-blocking as wearing multiple articles of solid-colored clothing in a single outfit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aol.com/article/2013/10/15/the-art-of-colorblocking/20743446/?swp=1|title=The art of colorblocking|first=AOL|last=Staff|publisher=}}</ref> Traditional color-blocking consists of putting together two or three different, but complementary colors together in one outfit.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fashiondujourdaily.wordpress.com/2011/03/10/color-blocking-101-what-how/|title=Color Blocking 101: What & How|first=FASHION du|last=jour|date=11 March 2011|publisher=}}</ref> It is also considered color-blocking even if the colors are not direct opposites on the color wheel. For example, yellow and orange are right next to each other, but adding purple (a color on the opposite of the wheel) creates a color-blocked outfit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://achicdirection.com/2011/03/29/what-is-color-blocking/|title=Protected Blog › Log in|website=achicdirection.com}}</ref>
==Rules== Fashion icons, designers, and figures have developed rules that go along with the art of color-blocking. Basic rules for color-blocking are centered on the colour theory. The colour theory states that there are unwritten rules in color-blocking such as not wearing too many colors together at once, and balancing an outfit with a neutral such as grey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/lifestyle/report-rules-of-colour-blocking-2012370|title=Rules of colour blocking - Latest News & Updates at Daily News & Analysis|date=21 August 2014|publisher=}}</ref>
==Benefits== Since color-blocking is an abstract form of art, it is easy to create illusions for accentuating body shapes, making people look taller and thinner. Color-blocking provides versatility to clothing that other trends and styles don't provide.<ref name="Rules of Colour blocking">{{cite web|title=Rules of Colour Blocking|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/lifestyle/report-rules-of-colour-blocking-2012370|website=DNA|accessdate=18 October 2015}}</ref>
==Interior design== Color-blocking has recently spilled over into home décor and interior design. This trend takes the same idea in home design that is does in fashion: the colors are paired with no concern of matching.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.decorlove.com/color-blocking-in-home-decor-tips-and-inspirations/|title=Color Blocking In Home Decor – Tips And Inspirations|date=23 May 2014|publisher=}}</ref> In the home color-blocking is used mainly in room décor and walls. Décor clashing with each other, or in more mild cases the opposite colors complement each other to provide an interesting and refreshing atmosphere in a room.
