{{Infobox person | name = Lynne Ramsay | image = Lynne Ramsay Cannes 2013.jpg | image_size = | caption = Ramsay at Cannes, 2013 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1969|12|5|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Glasgow]], Scotland | alma_mater = [[Edinburgh Napier University|Napier College]]
[[National Film and Television School]] | occupation = {{flatlist| *Film director *screenwriter *cinematographer}} | years_active = 1995–present | children = 1 | website = }} '''Lynne Ramsay''' (born 5 December 1969) is a Scottish film director, writer, producer, and cinematographer best known for the [[feature film]]s ''[[Ratcatcher (film)|Ratcatcher]]'' (1999), ''[[Morvern Callar (film)|Morvern Callar]]'' (2002), ''[[We Need to Talk About Kevin (film)|We Need to Talk About Kevin]]'' (2011), and ''[[You Were Never Really Here]]'' (2017). Her films are marked by a fascination with [[children]] and young people and the recurring themes of [[grief]], [[guilt (emotion)|guilt]], [[death]], and its aftermath. They are low on [[dialogue]] and explicit story exposition, and instead use images, vivid details, music, and [[sound design]] to create their worlds. In April 2013 she was selected as a member of the main competition jury at the [[2013 Cannes Film Festival]].{{cite web | url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/nicole-kidman-christopher-waltz-ang-lee-among-cannes-jury-members-1200410650/ | title=Nicole Kidman, Christopher Waltz, Ang Lee Among Cannes Jury Members | work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | publisher=[[Reed Business Information]] | date=23 April 2013 | accessdate=23 April 2013 | last=Saperstein | first=Pat}} In 2015, she was named as a member of the jury for the main competition at the [[72nd Venice International Film Festival|2015 Venice Film Festival]]. ==Early life and education== Born in [[Glasgow]] on 5 December 1969, Ramsay studied [[photography]] at [[Edinburgh Napier University|Napier College, Edinburgh]]. In 1995, she graduated from the [[National Film and Television School]] in [[Beaconsfield]], [[England]], where she specialised in [[cinematography]] and [[Film director|direction]]. ==Career== Ramsay took a break in-between ''Black and White Town'' and ''We Need to Talk About Kevin'', explaining she thinks the filmmaking process is different for her, and other writer-directors, than it is for directors who don’t write their own material. The [[Harvard Film Archive]] welcomed Lynne Ramsay for a showcase of her films, including the three acclaimed shorts that inaugurated her career.[http://hcl.harvard.edu/hfa/films/2012janmar/ramsay.html "Harvard Film Archive."] (Retrieved 5 May 2012) She experienced great personal frustration in her involvement with ''The Lovely Bones,'' during which personal and professional setbacks and mishandling saw her lose the job of directing to [[Peter Jackson]], whose version of the film received largely negative reviews. She stated in an interview with Oliver Lyttelton that "People started to call it 'The Lovely Money,' they were getting greedy around it. And I could feel the vibes. It became like the Holy Bible, I kept handing in drafts and I thought they were good, but it was like 'But that's not exactly like the book, the book's going to be a success.' That was the mistake they made with the project." She stated additionally that she considered Jackson's interpretation of the film, with a desire to stick as closely as possible to the original story, was partially responsible for what she considered the lacklustre quality of the finished product.{{cite news|last=Lyttelton|first=Oliver|title=Lynne Ramsay Talks Her Version Of 'The Lovely Bones,' Tilda Swinton Says More Adventures Are Coming|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/lynne_ramsay_talks_her_the_lovely_bones_tilda_swinton_says_she_thinks_of_he|accessdate=11 June 2012|newspaper=Indiewire|date=14 September 2012}} ===Short films=== Ramsay won the 1996 Cannes Prix de Jury for her graduation film, the short "Small Deaths". Her second short film, "Kill the Day", won the Clermont Ferrand Prix du Jury; her third, "Gasman", won her another Cannes Prix du Jury in addition to a Scottish BAFTA for Best Short Film. ''[[Small Deaths (film)|Small Deaths]]'' (1996) is Ramsay's debut short film that she completed as her graduating film at the UK's [[National Film and Television School]]. Small Deaths is a series of three vignettes of children grappling with familial realities and the repercussions of their actions. (1996, video, 11 minutes). Ramsay is the Writer, Director and cinematographer for this film.[http://www.walkerart.org/calendar/2012/double-feature-lynne-ramsay-early-shorts-and "Double Feature: Lynne Ramsay Early Shorts and Ratcatcher."] (Retrieved 5 May 2012) ''[[Kill the Day (film)|Kill the Day]]'' (1996), written and directed by Ramsay, captures a day in the life of a heroin addict recently released from jail, and in the process inventively probes the inner workings of memory (1996, 35mm, 17 minutes). ''[[Gasman (film)|Gasman]]'' (1998), also written and directed by Ramsay, is about a brother and sister who attend a Christmas party with their dad, and encounter two other children who are strangely familiar with him. (1998, video, 15 minutes). ''[[Swimmer (film)|Swimmer]]'' (2012), was co-commissioned by [[BBC Films]], Film4 and the [[London Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games]]. The short was nominated for the [[British Independent Film Awards]] (BIFA) in the category for Best Short Film. It won a [[BAFTA]] Award for Best Short Film at the [[66th British Academy Film Awards]] in 2013.{{cite web|title=BAFTAs 2013: Complete List Of Winners From This Year's BAFTA Awards|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2013/02/10/baftas-awards-2013-winners_n_2658184.html}} ===Feature films=== ''[[Ratcatcher (film)|Ratcatcher]]'' (1999), Ramsay's debut feature, won critical acclaim and numerous awards. It was screened at the [[1999 Cannes Film Festival]]{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/5373/year/1999.html |title=Festival de Cannes: Ratcatcher |accessdate=10 October 2009|work=festival-cannes.com}} and opened the [[Edinburgh International Film Festival]], winning her the Guardian New Directors prize. She also won the Carl Foreman Award for Newcomer in British Film at the 2000 BAFTA Awards, the Sutherland Trophy at the [[London Film Festival]] and the Silver Hugo for Best Director at the [[Chicago International Film Festival]]. ''[[Morvern Callar (film)|Morvern Callar]]'' (2002) won [[Samantha Morton]] the British Independent Film Award for Best Actress, and [[Kathleen McDermott]] the Scottish BAFTA Award for Best Actress. It also won the 2002 C.I.C.A.E. Award and the Award of The Youth at the [[2002 Cannes Film Festival]]. The motion picture soundtrack includes tracks from [[Stereolab]], [[Aphex Twin]], [[Broadcast (band)|Broadcast]], [[Velvet Underground]], and Nancy Sinatra. Ramsay is credited as the writer and director. The film is based on Alan Warner's 1995 novel of the same name, [[Morvern Callar]]. It was featured in the Directors Fortnight for the Cannes Film Festival 2002 and then went on to open the Edinburgh International Film Festival in August of the same year. The film also featured at the Telluride, Toronto, San Sebastian, Dinard and Stockholm Film Festivals of 2002. It was nominated for seven British Independent Film Awards. Ramsay was slated to direct the adaptation of [[Alice Sebold]]'s ''[[The Lovely Bones]]'', which she had read in manuscript form prior to its publication. She left the project in early 2004 after the novel had become a bestseller and the producers wanted a version more faithful to the original than she had been planning.{{cite news|last=Kois|first=Dan|title=Lynne Ramsay Is Back. Finally.|url=http://6thfloor.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/13/lynne-ramsay-is-back-finally/|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=13 January 2012|accessdate=14 January 2012}} ''[[We Need to Talk About Kevin (film)|We Need to Talk About Kevin]]'' (2011) was Ramsay's next feature-length film in which she was the writer, producer and director. The film, based on [[Lionel Shriver]]'s [[We Need to Talk About Kevin|novel]], is about a mother dealing with the aftermath of a school massacre committed by her son. Budgetary difficulties held the production up, but after several script drafts, the film, which employed a fragmented, elliptical narrative and starred [[Tilda Swinton]] as the tormented mother, premiered in 2011 to great acclaim at the [[Cannes Film Festival]].[http://www.screenonline.org.uk/people/id/552070/index.html "Screen Online: Lynne, Ramsay".] "BFI Screen Online" (Retrieved: 5 May 2012) Ramsay went on to receive a [[BAFTA]] nomination for Best Director as well as taking the Best Director prize at the [[British Independent Film Awards]], and a win for Best Film Screenplay at the Writer's Guild of Great Britain. In 2013 Ramsay was slated to direct ''[[Jane Got a Gun]]''. [[Natalie Portman]] signed on to star and produce the film as the farmer wife of an outlaw husband, who, after his gang turns on him, she must defend with the help of an old lover. In March 2013 Ramsay left the project due to creative differences with producers{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/03/shocker-jane-got-a-gun-loses-director-lynne-ramsay-on-first-day-of-production/ |title=Director Lynne Ramsay Bails Out Of 'Jane Got A Guy' Movie On First Day |publisher=Deadline.com |date= |accessdate=2013-05-15}}and funders, including over the latter's demand for a happy ending.https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/25/lynne-ramsay-director-you-were-never-really-here-observer-interview She was replaced by [[Gavin O'Connor (director)|Gavin O'Connor]].{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/03/warrior-helmer-gavin-oconnor-rides-to-rescue-on-jane-got-a-gun/ |title=Gavin O'Connor Replaces AWOL Director Lynne Ramsay On 'Jane Got A Gun' |publisher=Deadline.com |date=2013-03-20 |accessdate=2013-05-15}} Actor [[Jude Law]] also left the production shortly after.{{cite web|last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/03/more-fallout-on-jane-got-a-gun-jude-law-exits-picture/ |title=Jude Law Latest To Depart Troubled 'Jane Got A Gun' Movie |publisher=Deadline.com |date= |accessdate=2013-05-15}} Lynne Ramsay is scheduled to direct a modern adaptation of [[Herman Melville]]'s ''[[Moby Dick]]''. She has stated that the film will be set in space, and deal with themes of [[psychology]] and [[claustrophobia]], quoting "So we're creating a whole new world, and a new alien. [It's] a very psychological piece, mainly taking place in the ship, a bit like ''[[Das Boot]]'', so it's quite claustrophobic. It's another monster movie, cos the monster's Ahab."{{cite news|last=Child|first=Ben|title=Lynne Ramsay to steer Moby-Dick into outer space|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/oct/25/lynne-ramsay-moby-dick-space|accessdate=9 June 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=25 October 2011}} Ramsay directed ''[[You Were Never Really Here]]'', an adaptation of [[Jonathan Ames]]'s novella of the same name. It premiered to wide critical acclaim in competition at the [[70th Cannes Film Festival]] in 2017, where it received a seven-minute standing ovation, and Ramsay won the [[Best Screenplay Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Best Screenplay]] award. The film, starring [[Joaquin Phoenix]], was released by [[Amazon Studios]].{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/cannes-a24-buys-joaquin-phoenixs-you-were-never-really-here-exclusive-1201773661/|title=Cannes: Amazon Sweeps in To Buy Joaquin Phoenix’s ‘You Were Never Really Here’|last=Setoodeh|first=Elsa Keslassy,Ramin|date=2016-05-13|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-25}} In 2018 Ramsay said in an interview that she was working on her new film, a comedy.{{Cite news|url=https://forlackofabetterreview.com/2018/03/08/in-conversation-with-lynne-ramsay/|title=In Conversation with Lynne Ramsay|date=2018-03-08|work=For Lack Of A Better Review|access-date=2018-03-14|language=en-US}} ===Acclaim=== In 2007 Ramsay was rated number 12 in Guardian Unlimited's list of the world's 40 best directors working at that time.[http://film.guardian.co.uk/features/page/0,11456,1082823,00.html "Film Features: The world's 40 best directors… 12. Lynne Ramsay"] ''Guardian.co.uk'' (Retrieved: 6 July 2009) ===Personal=== Ramsay divorced in 2013, and has one daughter.https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/25/lynne-ramsay-director-you-were-never-really-here-observer-interview ===Music promos=== Ramsay directed the promotional video for the Manchester-based [[indie-rock]] band [[Doves (band)|Doves]]' single [[Doves discography#Singles|"Black and White Town"]], which was released on 7 February 2005. However, Ramsay's version was re-edited and the released version was significantly different from her original piece.[http://www.academyfilms.com/flash/#/academy/music_videos/lynne_ramsay/doves_black_and_white_town "MUSC VIDEOS: Lynne Ramsay — Doves: "Black and White Town"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100420105042/http://www.academyfilms.com/flash |date=2010-04-20 }} ''AcademyFilms.com'' (Retrieved: 6 July 2009) ==Praise and criticism== Ramsay is known for the outspoken praise and criticism she receives from her industry contemporaries. [[Sean O'Hagan (journalist)|Sean O'Hagan]] wrote in ''[[The Guardian]]'' that her "Ramsay is entertaining company, whether talking about the art films she loves —by [[Ingmar Bergman|Bergman]], [[John Cassavetes|Cassavetes]], [[Rainer Werner Fassbinder|Fassbinder]]— or railing against the 'bullshitters and backstabbers' of the film industry."{{cite news|last=O'Hagan|first=Sean|authorlink = Sean O'Hagan (journalist) | title=Lynne Ramsay: 'Just talk to me straight'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/oct/02/lynne-ramsay-interview-about-kevin|accessdate=8 June 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=1 October 2011}} The Harvard Film Archive describes Ramsay as "an uncompromising filmmaker fascinated by the tremendous power of cinema to appeal directly to the senses and awaken new depths in our audio-visual imagination. Immersive and at times almost overwhelming, Ramsay's films abound with uncommon imagery arresting for its remarkable use of texture, composition, color, music and sound."{{cite web|title=Lynne Ramsay and the Senses of Cinema|url=http://hcl.harvard.edu/hfa/films/2012janmar/ramsay.html|publisher=Harvard Film Archive|accessdate=8 June 2012}} In her ''[[The New York Times]]'' biography, Ramsay's work is described as having a "gritty, realistic visual style that demands attention." [[Tilda Swinton]], whom Ramsey directed in ''We Need To Talk About Kevin'', called her "the real McCoy", saying, "She is one of those rare directors who creates the kind of films that just would not be there if she didn't make them." British film critic Jonathan Romney, when speaking on ''We Need To Talk About Kevin'', opined "Ramsay, thinks not in concepts but in images. She doesn't make intellectual films, but ones that are close to music, taking visuals to the point of abstraction."{{cite news|last=Romney|first=Jonathan|title=We Need to Talk About Kevin, Lynne Ramsay, 112 mins (15)|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/reviews/we-need-to-talk-about-kevin-lynne-ramsay-112-mins-15-2374467.html|accessdate=8 June 2012|newspaper=The Independent|date=23 October 2011}} ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' columnist Mark Olsen considered Ramsay "one of the leading lights of young British cinema", describing her additionally as "among the most celebrated British filmmakers of her generation."{{cite news|last=Olsen|first=Mark|title=Indie Focus: Lynne Ramsay talks about 'Kevin'|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/jan/05/news/la-en-indie-focus-20120105|accessdate=8 June 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=5 January 2012}} ==Awards== On 8 October 2013, Ramsay was awarded an honorary doctorate by the [[University of Edinburgh]] for her contribution to British film.{{cite news|accessdate=2018-05-12|title=A celebration of achievement|url=http://www.ed.ac.uk/news/2013/celebrationofachievement-041013|newspaper=University of Edinburgh}} ==Filmography== {|class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:33px;"|Year ! rowspan="2" style="width:200px;"|Title ! colspan=3 |Role ! rowspan=2 |Description |- ! width=65 |Director ! width=65 |Writer ! width=65 |Cinematographer |- |rowspan=3|1996 |''Small Deaths'' |{{ya}} |{{ya}} |{{ya}} |Short film |- |''Kill the Day'' |{{ya}} |{{ya}} | |Short film |- |''Sweet Heart'' | | |{{ya}} |Short film |- |rowspan=2|1997 |''Gasman'' |{{ya}} |{{ya}} | |Short film |- |''One Eye'' | | |{{ya}} |Short film |- |1999 |''[[Ratcatcher (film)|Ratcatcher]]'' |{{ya}} |{{ya}} | | |- |2002 |''[[Morvern Callar (film)|Morvern Callar]]'' |{{ya}} |{{ya}} | | |- |2005 |''Black and White Town'' |{{ya}} | | |Music video |- |2011 |''[[We Need to Talk About Kevin (film)|We Need to Talk About Kevin]]'' |{{ya}} |{{ya}} | | |- |2012 |''[[Swimmer (film)|Swimmer]]'' |{{ya}} | | |Short film |- |2017 |''[[You Were Never Really Here]]'' |{{ya}} |{{ya}} | | |- |} ==See also== {{Portal|biography}} * [[List of female film and television directors]] * [[Women's cinema]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=0708903|name=Lynne Ramsay}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100420105042/http://www.academyfilms.com/flash#/academy/music_videos/lynne_ramsay/ Profile: Lynne Ramsay] ''AcademyFilms.com'' {{Lynne Ramsay}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ramsay, Lynne}} [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Scottish women film directors]] [[Category:Scottish women cinematographers]] [[Category:Alumni of the National Film and Television School]] [[Category:BAFTA winners (people)]] [[Category:People from Glasgow]] [[Category:Scottish screenwriters]] [[Category:Scottish film producers]] [[Category:Scottish cinematographers]] [[Category:Alumni of Edinburgh Napier University]] [[Category:WFTV Award winners]]

revision.comment: Rock reliefs are a prominent aspect of [[Hittite art]].
revision.text:
[[File:KybeleManisa.JPG|thumb|300px|Manisa relief]] {{Location map | Turkey | width = 300 | caption = Location of the Manisa relief in Turkey | relief = 1 | lat_deg = 38 | lat_min = 35 | lat_sec = 52 | lat_dir = N | lon_deg = 27 | lon_min = 30 | lon_sec = 0 | lon_dir = E }} The '''Manisa relief''', also known as the '''Akpınar relief''' and the '''Cybele relief''' ({{Lang-tr|'Taş Suret'}} (Cliff image) or '''Sipil Heykeli''' (Sipylos Monument)), is a Hittite [[rock relief]] at Akpınar, about 5 km east of the Turkish provincial capital of [[Manisa]] above an amusement park on the road to [[Salihli]]. It depicts a [[Hittite mythology|Hittite]] divinity. Rock reliefs are a prominent aspect of [[Hittite art]].
== Description == [[File:KybeleStatue19thCenturyPostcardMountSipylusManisaTurkey.jpg|thumb|left|Depiction on a French postcard, c.1900]] The relief is located in a niche about 100-120 m up a granite cliff-face of [[Mount Sipylus]], overlooking the city of Manisa, the ancient [[Lydia]]n city of [[Magnesia ad Sipylum]], and the [[Gediz River|Gediz]] river valley (the ancient Hermos). It is over 6 m high and in poor condition.
A seated figure 8-10 m high is depicted in high relief (but not completely separated from the cliff face), who looks northwards and wears a tall pointed headdress. Its hands seem to rest on its breasts, the feet rest atop a footstool. The head has partly cleaved away, from natural causes.<ref>G.E. Bean, ''Aegean Turkey: an archaeological guide'', vol. ii, pp 31-33 and pl. 3; C. P. Jones, "A Geographical Setting for the Baucis and Philemon Legend (Ovid ''Metamorphoses'' 8.611-724)" ''Harvard Studies in Classical Philology'' '''96''' (1994:203-23 and pls. I-IV) pp 210f, with bibliography.</ref>
Two remnants of [[Luwian hieroglyphs|Luwian hieroglyphic]] inscriptions are visible to the right of his head, which indicate that the relief dates to the Hittite period. [[Cecil John Cadoux]] thought a date in the time of [[Suppiluliuma I]] or his son [[Mursili II]] (i.e. 14th century BC) was probable.<ref> Cecil John Cadoux: ''Ancient Smyrna. A history of the city from the earliest times to 324 A.D.'' Blackwell, Oxford 1938, pp. 25-26.</ref> [[Helmuth Theodor Bossert]] read the leftmost inscription (Akpınar 1) as "Prince Kuwalanamuwa", the same name which is found on the [[Hanyeri relief]], but it is unclear whether both refer to the same individual. The right inscription (Akpınar 2) was not legible to [[Hans Gustav Güterbock]], who studied the relief with R.A. Alexander in 1978.<ref name="Ehringhaus">Horst Ehringhaus: ''Götter, Herrscher, Inschriften.'' 2005, p. 87.</ref>
== Reception == In the second century AD, [[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]] recorded the figure in his ''Description of Greece'' as a depiction of the mother goddess, [[Cybele]], made by [[Broteas]] the son pf [[Tantalos]].<ref>Pausanias 3.22.4 [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Paus.3.22.4&fromdoc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0160, English translation].</ref> Several travellers in the 18th and 19th centuries described the work, including [[Richard Chandler]], [[Charles Texier]], [[Gustav Hirschfeld]] and [[Archibald Henry Sayce]].<ref name="Ehringhaus"/> The interpretation of the figure is disputed. Bossert's identification with Cybele was rejected by [[Kurt Bittel]] as unsustainable, but he still saw a female goddess,<ref>Kurt Bittel. "Kubaba – Kybele." in [[Erich Ebeling]], [[Bruno Meissner]], [[Dietz Otto Edzard]] (ed.): ''[[Reallexikon der Assyriologie und vorderasiatischen Archäologie]].'' Vol. 6: ''Klagegesang – Libanon.'' Walter de Gruyter, Berlin 1983, {{ISBN|3-11-010051-7}}, p. 264, [https://books.google.com/books?id=OIeiZaIo91IC&pg=PA264&dq=manisa+kybele&as_brr=3&cd=8#v=onepage&q=manisa%20kybele&f=false in Google Books].</ref> as did [[Ekrem Akurgal]]. Peter Z. Spanos, however, interprets the figure as the Weather god,<ref>Peter Z. Spanos: "Einige Bemerkungen zum sogenannten Niobe-Monument bei Manisa (Magnesia ad Sipylum)." ''Beiträge zur Altertumskunde Kleinasiens. Festschrift für Kurt Bittel.'' Zabern, Mainz 1983, pp. 477-483.</ref> which conforms to the general tendency today to interpret the image as a male god; Ehringhaus suggests it is a mountain god.<ref name="Ehringhaus"/>
As a result of confusion with a different natural rock formation near Manisa, which resembles a sitting figure and is known as ''Weeping [[Niobe]]'', this relief is sometimes, incorrectly, known as the ''Niobe cliffs''.
== References ==
<references />
== Bibliography == * [[Kay Kohlmeyer]]. "Felsbilder der hethitischen Großreichszeit." ''Acta Praehistorica et Archaeologica'' 15 (1983) pp. 28-34. * Peter Z. Spanos: "Einige Bemerkungen zum sogenannten Niobe-Monument bei Manisa (Magnesia ad Sipylum)." ''Beiträge zur Altertumskunde Kleinasiens. Festschrift für Kurt Bittel.'' Zabern, Mainz 1983, pp. 477-483. * [[Maarten J. Vermaseren]]. ''Corpus Cultus Cybelae Attidisque (CCCA)'' Vol. 1: ''Asia Minor'' (= ''Etudes préliminaires aux religions orientales dans l'Empire Romain'' Vol. 50.1). Brill, Leiden. 1987, {{ISBN|90-04-05399-9}}, p. 129, [https://books.google.com/books?id=mj-F_DX60nMC&pg=PA129&dq=manisa+kybele&lr=&as_brr=3&cd=18#v=onepage&q=manisa%20kybele&f=false in Google Books]. * [[Horst Ehringhaus]]. ''Götter, Herrscher, Inschriften. Die Felsreliefs der hethitischen Großreichszeit in der Türkei.'' Zabern, Mainz 2005, {{ISBN|3-8053-3469-9}}, pp. 84–87.

{{Infobox company | name=Mithun, Inc. | type=[[Privately held company|Private]] | industry=[[Architecture]] | founded={{Start date and age|1949}} | founder=Omer Mithun | hq_location_city=[[Seattle, Washington]] | hq_location_country=United States | website=http://www.mithun.com/ }}
'''Mithun, Inc.''' ('''Mithun''') is a [[multidisciplinary]] [[professional services]] firm headquartered in the city of [[Seattle]] in [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] state in the [[United States|United States of America]] offering [[integrated design]] services related to [[architecture]], [[land use planning]], [[landscape architecture]], [[interior architecture]], [[interior design]], and "cultural audits" with a focus on [[sustainability]].
==History==
The firm was founded in 1949 by Omer Mithun, a professor of architecture at the [[University of Washington]]<ref>{{cite web | author=Marga Rose Hancock Hon. AIA | title=Honors Archive: Omer Mithun FAIA 1918-1983 | url=http://www.aiaseattle.org/archive_honors_fellows_mithun.htm | work= | publisher=AIA Seattle | date= | accessdate=2008-05-15 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080521034552/http://www.aiaseattle.org/archive_honors_fellows_mithun.htm | archivedate=2008-05-21 | df= }}</ref> as a private practice in [[Bellevue, Washington]]. Mithun incorporated in 1953, and became Mithun Partners in 1988. The practice moved into the historic [[Times Square Building]] in 1990, after the firm outgrew the space they moved again in 2000, after renovating their present-day headquarters on Pier 56. Mithun is now led by a board of directors, presided by Bert Gregory, FAIA, who also serves as [[Chief executive officer|CEO]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Macaulay | first = David R. | title = Integrated Design - Mithun | publisher = Ecotone Publishing | year = 2008 | location = Bainbridge Island, Washington | pages = 11–22 | url = http://www.ecotonedesign.com/ecotone/bookstore/bookdetail.asp?ID=37 | isbn = 978-0-9749033-9-2 }}</ref>
[[File:REI flagship seattle.jpg|thumb|Mithun-designed REI Flagship Store in Seattle, Washington, USA, 2005]]
==Notable works== ===Buildings===
*'''Epler Hall at [[Portland State University]]''' - six-story, {{convert|65000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} dormitory <ref>{{cite web|author=Earth Share of Washington |title=Mithun & the Environment - An Interview with Bert Gregory |url=http://www.esw.org/giving/mithun.html |work=Green Business |publisher=Earth Share of Washington |date= |accessdate=2008-05-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071111212551/http://www.esw.org/giving/mithun.html |archivedate=November 11, 2007 }}</ref> *'''[[IslandWood]]''' (formerly the Puget Sound Environmental Learning Center) (2002) - [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]]-NC Gold rated. Nationally recognized project and environmental case study featuring low-impact construction, recycled materials, photovoltaics and a custom-designed LivingMachine<sup>TM</sup> to treat grey-water and black-water on site.<ref>{{cite web | author= | title=HPB CaseStudy: Overview - IslandWood | url=http://www.buildinggreen.com/hpb/overview.cfm?projectid=497 | work=High Performance Buildings Case Studies | publisher=BuildingGreen, LLC | date=21 December 2006 | accessdate=2008-05-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite paper |author = Cascadia Green Building Council |title = Puget Sound Environmental Learning Center |date = 2002-04-22 |url = http://www.cascadiagbc.org/resources/case-studies/pugetsoundcasestudy.pdf |format = [[PDF]] |accessdate = 2008-05-15 |journal = |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20081202112627/http://www.cascadiagbc.org/resources/case-studies/pugetsoundcasestudy.pdf |archive-date = 2008-12-02 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> *'''REI Flagship Store''' (1996) - "the apotheosis of the exposed-viscera school of architecture -- all the building's structural guts are on glorious exhibit, from the electric conduits to the I-beams and turnbuckles that hold everything together." <ref>{{cite news | author= | title=Seattle Visitor's Guide: REI Flagship Store (1996) | url=http://www.seattlepi.com/visitorsguide/entry.asp?ID=150 | work= | publisher=Seattle Post-Intelligencer | date= | accessdate=2008-05-15 }} {{Dead link|date=January 2012|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| author=Seattle Daily Journal of Commerce | title=Mithun Partners | url=http://www.djc.com/special/century/mithun.html | work=Top Projects of the Century in Washington State | date=9 December 1999 | accessdate=2008-05-15}}</ref>
===Research & Planning===
*'''Blue Ring''' (1999) - Seattle's open space strategy for the Center City. The two reports [http://www.seattle.gov/dpd/stellent/groups/pan/@pan/@plan/@citydesign/documents/web_informational/dpds_006515.pdf Blue Ring, The Next Decade] and [http://www.seattle.gov/dpd/stellent/groups/pan/@pan/@plan/@citydesign/documents/web_informational/dpds_006516.pdf Blue Ring, the Next 100 Years] were conceived as a companion to the [[Olmsted Brothers]]' green ring of parks and parkways that encircle Seattle.<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| title =Seattle Department of Planning and Development - CityDesign Projects| url =http://www.seattle.gov/dpd/Planning/CityDesign/What_We_Do/UrbanDesignProjects/default.asp| accessdate =2008-05-15| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20080706043417/http://www.seattle.gov/dpd/Planning/CityDesign/What_We_Do/UrbanDesignProjects/default.asp| archivedate =2008-07-06| df =}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | title = ASLA 2003 Analysis and Planning Honor Award | url=http://www.asla.org/awards/2003/the_blue_ring.htm | accessdate = 2008-05-15 }}</ref> *'''Center for Urban Agriculture'''(2007) - conceptual design of an off-grid 318-unit multi family building that is energy and water self-sufficient by utilizing on site greenhouses, rooftop gardens, a chicken farm, and areas for growing vegetables and grains. The design exercise won "Best of Show", lauded as "most visionary" in the Cascadia Region Green Building Council's Living Building Challenge.<ref>{{cite news | author=Katie Zemtseff | title=Mithun and Perkins + Will win green design contest | url=http://www.djc.com/news/en/11188954.html | work=Seattle Daily Journal of Commerce | date=1 May 2007 | accessdate=2008-05-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author=Jacob Resneck | title=Mithun Urban Farms | url=http://www.coolhunting.com/archives/2007/09/mithun_urban_fa.php | work=CoolHunting | date=17 September 2007 | accessdate=2008-05-15}}</ref> *'''[https://web.archive.org/web/20080601044724/http://www.pdc.us/pubs/inv_detail.asp?id=332&ty=17 Lloyd Crossing Sustainable Urban Design Plan]''' (2004)- includes onsite and offsite strategies contribute to the capability of a 35-block ecosystem in [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], [[Oregon]], [[United States|USA]], emulating the natural systems of a pristine forest, even as the area's density increases fivefold. The plan received national recognition including the [[American Institute of Architects]] 2006 Institute Honor Awards for Regional and Urban Design,<ref>{{cite press release |title = Mithun Wins Prestigious AIA Honor Award for Lloyd Crossing |publisher = Portland Development Commission |date = 2006-01-18 |url = http://www.pdc.us/new/releases/2006/0124.asp |accessdate = 2008-05-15 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070807080643/http://www.pdc.us/new/releases/2006/0124.asp |archivedate = 2007-08-07 |df = }}</ref> a 2005 AIA/COTE Top Ten Green Projects <ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | title = AIA/COTE Top Ten Green Projects: Lloyd Crossing Sustainable Design Plan | url=http://www.aiatopten.org/hpb/overview.cfm?ProjectID=467 | accessdate = 2008-05-15 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last = Enlow |first = Clair |author-link = Clair Enlow |title = A Green Blueprint |newspaper = [[Metropolis (architecture magazine)|Metropolis Magazine]] |volume = 2005 |issue = August/September |pages = |date = July 2005 |url = http://www.metropolismag.com/cda/story.php?artid=1510 |postscript = <!--None--> |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080221231332/http://www.metropolismag.com/cda/story.php?artid=1510 |archivedate = 2008-02-21 |df = }}</ref>

'''Molse School''', ''translated as "School of Mol",'' is a common term for some international paint artists or a specific genre of paintings in late 19th and early 20th century. The paintings typically show picturesque and rustic places, farms, ... of the [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[municipality]] [[Mol, Belgium|Mol]], which is located in the [[Campine]]. The most famous painters of the ''Molse School'' were [[Jakob Smits]] and [[Dirk Baksteen]] who lived in Achterbos, a hamlet of Mol.
Based upon the [[Barbizon school]] the municipality Mol organized an international art [[exhibition]] in 1907 and invited painters from all over the world. Most of these artists had not met before and their only connection was their stay in a local [[hotel]] during the exhibition. These artists were not tied by a fine art society, neither was there a common style. In total 68 artists participated at this event, showing 212 works. This exhibition was also an attempt to show the artists the beauty of Mol, its [[heath]], the white sand flats and how the inhabitants (mostly [[farmer]]s) lived. This attempt succeeded.
Upon their return home, the artists showed their paintings to their colleagues. This resulted in those colleagues also coming over to Mol making painting [[en plein air]] popular.
Some artists commonly categorized under the ''Molse School'' are [[Dirk Baksteen]], [[Gerard Baksteen]], [[Charles Claessens]], [[Leon Delderenne]], [[Paul Mathieu]], [[Ernest Midy]], [[Erneste Rinquet]], [[Jakob Smits]], [[Willem Battaille]], [[Emile Van Damme-Sylva]], [[Paula Van Rompa-Zenke]], [[Gaston De Biemme]]
<gallery> File:Jacob Smits Het Gehucht.jpg|"The Hamlet" (Jacob Smits) File:Paul Mathieu 001.jpg|"Old houses on a sunny afternoon" (Paul Mathieu) File:Willem Battaille 001.JPG|"Along the river" (Willem Bataille) </gallery>

{{For|the novelist|Pierce Egan the Younger}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} '''Pierce Egan''' (1772–1849) was a British journalist, [[sportswriter]], and writer on popular culture. ==Life== Egan's parents were [[Irish people|Irish]] migrants, but he may have been born in the London area. He went into the printing trade, and was a compositor for [[George Smeeton]] in 1812.{{cite ODNB|id=8577|title=Egan, Pierce|first=Dennis|last=Brailsford}} He established himself as the country's leading reporter of sporting events, which at the time meant mainly prize-fights and horse-races. It was Egan who first defined boxing as "the sweet science". He is buried in [[Highgate Cemetery]], North London. ==Works== Four volumes of ''[[Boxiana|Boxiana; or Sketches of Ancient and Modern Pugilism]]'' appeared, lavishly illustrated, between 1813 and 1824. Following a dispute with his publisher, Egan was replaced for the fourth ''Boxiana'' volume (replaced by 'Jon Bee'), the court permitting Egan continued rights to the title provided he used the ''New Series'' prefix. Two volumes of Egan's ''New Series Boxiana'' were published in 1828/29.Snowdon, David, ''Writing the Prizefight: Pierce Egan's 'Boxiana' World'' (2013) In 1821 Egan announced the publication of a regular journal: ''Life in London'', appearing monthly at a shilling a time. It was to be illustrated by [[George Cruikshank]] (1792–1878), and was dedicated to the King, [[George IV of the United Kingdom|George IV]], who at one time had received Egan at court. The first edition of ''Life in London or, the Day and Night Scenes of Jerry Hawthorn, esq., and his elegant friend, Corinthian Tom, accompanied by Bob Logic, the Oxonian, in their rambles and sprees through the Metropolis'' appeared on 15 July 1821. Egan's creation was an instant success. Pirate versions appeared, featuring such figures as 'Bob Tallyho', 'Dick Wildfire' and the like. Print-makers speedily knocked off cuts featuring the various 'stars' and the real-life public flocked to the 'sporting' addresses that Egan had his heroes frequent. There was a translation into French. At least six plays were based on Egan's characters, contributing to yet more sales. One of these was exported to America, launching the ''Tom and Jerry'' craze there. The version created by [[William Thomas Moncrieff]] was praised as ''The Beggar's Opera of its day''. Moncrieff's production of ''[[Tom and Jerry, or Life in London]]'' ran continuously at the Adelphi Theatre for two seasons and it was the dramatist's work as much as the author's that did so much to popularise the book's trademark use of fashionable slang. ''Life in London'' appeared until 1828, when Egan closed it down. Egan published a report of the trial of John Thurtell and Joseph Hunt, for [[Radlett murder|the murder of William Weare]]. Thurtell allegedly mentioned, just seven hours before his execution, that among his final wishes was a desire to read Egan's coverage of a recent prizefight. Egan wrote also satirical legal pieces such as ''The Fancy Tog's Man versus Young Sadboy, the Milling Quaker''. In 1824 he launched a new journal, ''Pierce Egan's Life in London and Sporting Guide'', a weekly newspaper priced at eightpence-halfpenny. Other works included sporting anecdotes, theatrical autobiographies, guide-books, and 'fancy ditties'. Among his later efforts, in 1838, was a series of pieces on the delights to be found on and immediately adjacent to the Thames. It was dedicated, with permission, to the young Queen Victoria and featured the illustrative work of his son [[Pierce Egan the Younger]]. In 1823 Egan produced an edition of [[Francis Grose]]'s ''Classical Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue'' (1785 et seq.), including mainly sporting Regency slang. He also cut the "coarse" and "broad" expressions' which Grose had allowed, and noted the way that some slang terminology, typically ''rum'' – once a positive term, but by 1820 generally the reverse – had altered. Don Atyeo wrote in his study of ''Violence in Sport'' (1979) that
''Boxiana'' is riddled with "Fancy" slang: '"Ogles" were blackened, "peepers" plunged into darkness, "tripe-shops" received "staggerers", "ivories" were cracked, "domino boxes" shattered, and "claret" flowed in a steady stream.*{{citation |last=Atyeo |first=Don |title=Blood & Guts: Violence in Sports |edition=illustrated |publisher=Grosset & Dunlap |year=1979 |isbn=9780709200000 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?redir_esc=y&id=Yj0TAQAAIAAJ&dq=F-troop+%22them+and+sending%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=ogles- 146]}}
And as Egan's character Corinthian Tom explains in ''Life in London'',
A kind of ''cant'' phraseology is current from one end of the Metropolis to the other, and you will scarcely be able to move a single step, my dear JERRY, without consulting a ''Slang'' Dictionary, or having some friend at your elbow to explain the strange expressions which, at every turn, will assail your ear.' Such a dictionary is what Egan offers, hoping in sum that his efforts work 'to improve, and not to degrade mankind; to remove ''ignorance'', and put the UNWARY on their guard; to rouse the ''sleepy'', and to keep them AWAKE; to render those persons who are a little UP, more FLY: and to cause every one to be ''down'' to those tricks, manoeuvres and impositions practised in life, which daily cross the paths of both young and old.
==Influence== [[John Camden Hotten]] brought out a reprint of ''Life in London'' in 1869. "Tom and Jerry", the celebrated duo, have been perpetuated in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's [[Tom and Jerry|cartoon cat and mouse]], and as the male protagonists of the 1970s' BBC television sitcom ''[[The Good Life (1975 TV series)|The Good Life]]''. ==In literature== Pierce Egan was one of the narrators of [[George MacDonald Fraser]]'s book ''[[Black Ajax]]'', about [[Tom Molineaux]] and his quest for the heavyweight championship of England. One chapter of the book also featured schoolboy versions of Egan's characters from ''Life in London''. ==Publications== Journals: * [[Boxiana]] * ''Life in London'' Books: *''Boxiana'', vol. 1 (1813) *''Boxiana'', vol. 2 (1818) *''Boxiana'', vol. 3 (1821) * ''Life in London'' (1821) * ''Sporting Anecdotes'' (1821) * ''Finish to the Adventures of Tom and Jerry'' (1828) *''New Series Boxiana'', vol. 1 (1828) *''New Series Boxiana'', vol. 2 (1829) * ''Pierce Egan's Book of Sports And Mirror of Life: Embracing the turf, the chase, the ring, and the stage'' (1832) * ''The Pilgrims of the Thames in Search of the National'' (1838) * ''The Flower Of The Flock, Volume I-III'' (1865) Adaptations: * ''Life in London'' was adapted for the stage as [[Tom and Jerry, or Life in London]] (1821) and for radio [http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/lifeinlondon/ BBC] (2006). ==References== {{Reflist}} * John Sutherland (1989) ''The Longman Companion to Victorian Literature'', Longman/Stanford University Press (US) as ''The Stanford Companion to Victorian Literature'' * "Egan, Pierce James", ''Dictionary of Nineteenth-Century Journalism,'' ed. Laurel Brake and Marysa Demoor, British Library/ Academia, 2008, p. 195 * {{cite book |last=Reid |first=J.C. |title=Bucks and Bruisers: Pierce Egan and Regency England |year=1971 |publisher=Routledge & Kegan Paul |location=London |isbn=0710069677}} ==Further reading== * Jonathan Farina, "Flash Reading: The Currency of Knowing in ''Tom and Jerry''," ''The Wordsworth Circle'' 41.3 (Summer 2010): 150-54 * David Snowdon, ''Writing the Prizefight: Pierce Egan's 'Boxiana' World'' (Bern: Peter Lang, 2013) ==External links== * {{Gutenberg author | id=Egan,+Pierce | name=Pierce Egan}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Pierce Egan}} * {{Librivox author |id=738}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Egan, Pierce}} [[Category:1772 births]] [[Category:1849 deaths]] [[Category:British sportswriters]] [[Category:British male journalists]] [[Category:English non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Writers from London]] [[Category:19th-century theatre]] [[Category:Boxing writers]] [[Category:English male non-fiction writers]]
